**34 :octicon-issue-opened:** (created issue #1316: E2E Testing does not test issue.service.ts)
</div>

%%[created at: 2025 Feb 08 18:53:00]%%

**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Our current e2e testing mocks the issue service to store the issues, while the mocked github service does not handle issue storage at all. However, issue services originally does not have any direct dependencies on external api calls to github. So, it should not be necessary to mock issue services.

By not mocking issue services, we enable e2e testing to test issue.service.ts as well. It is also more in line with how CATcher works, with issue.services.ts asking for data from github.service.ts.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
We could remove mock.issue.service.ts and move the logic to mock.github.service.ts.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
The alternative would be to continue mocking the issue service, allowing mock.issue.service.ts to handle all logic to do with mutating issues.

**Additional context**
For example, the following function is found in mock.issue.service.ts, meaning mock.github.service.ts has no access to the issues created here.

<panel type="info" popup-url="https://github.com/CATcher-org/WATcher/issues/444#issuecomment-2739867936" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**41 :octicon-comment:** (commented on issue #444)
</div>

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 20 18:21:54]%%

It's probably best to eventually refactor it, but for now I think we can just check the issueOrPr field if we want to get this out the door.

Some things that we should discuss with regards to this feature:

### 1. How to handle multiple PRs fixing the same issue?

There can be multiple PRs fixing the same issue and one PR can fix multiple issues. My suggestion would be to simply display the issue under every PR that claims to fix it. This brings up a separate question of what count should we display? Inclusive or exclusive of duplicates?

### 2. How to handle closed PRs?

If a PR has been closed, we probably don't want to display any issues that it claims to fix under it, so we should probably just ignore closed PRs. This is separate from merged PRs, which we do want to display the fixed issues under.

### 3. How to handle if a PR fixes an issue assigned to another user?

Should we still display the issue under User A's PR if it fixes an issue assigned to User B? I think we should still display it.

### 4. How should this feature be toggled?

Should it be on at all times? Should we add a button to the filter bar? I think it would be okay to keep it on, since if the user wants to search or sort for a specific issue they can always just filter out PRs.



</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Feb 05 22:31:15]%%

This change is to make the workflow when restoring issues identical to deleting issues. If we were to use `updateLocalStore`, the issue remains in the `Issues deleted` table until the next filtering is run in `IssuesDataTable`
<img width="843" alt="Screenshot 2025-02-05 at 7 54 35 PM" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/cdac82d2-e690-4cb9-b55b-5eba6576dd0e" />

This would seem counter intuitive, see the following video:

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/bec6fef8-62c9-4874-bfe6-9de9272cc592


Hence, I changed the the `undeleteIssue` function to use `deleteFromLocalStore` instead, so that it will disappear immediately after the restore, and during the next issue polling, reappear in the issue posted table (Identical behaviour to deleting issues). I have checked the usage of this `undeleteIssue` function and it is only used originally to undo the delete action, and now also used by the new restore icon. A sample of the result is as follows:

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/a7979950-dbc0-4ab6-94cf-3880a3fbf553


</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Feb 09 16:42:10]%%

Ahhh this was my bad, I wasn't aware that `finalize` worked like that.

After understanding more on how `finalize` and `subscribe` works, I believe we would still need to use `finalize` here for the logic that removes the issues from `issuesPendingDeletion` list (if not when the deletion fails, the UI will continuous display the spinner icon), I have refactored the code block as follows:
```
this.issueService
  .deleteIssue(id)
  .pipe(finalize(() => ``{``
    const ``{`` [id]: issueRemoved, ...theRest ``}`` = this.issuesPendingDeletion;
    this.issuesPendingDeletion = theRest;
  ``}``))
  .subscribe(
    (removedIssue) => this.handleIssueDeletionSuccess(id, event, actionUndoable),
    (error) => this.errorHandlingService.handleError(error) 
  );
```

</panel>

<div slot="header">

**53 :octicon-issue-opened:** (created issue #429: Update deployment workflow to allow manual deployments from tag)
</div>

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 10 12:37:41]%%

Currently the deployment workflow in WATcher is different from CATcher.

CATcher:
1. PR to main, updating the version
2. Create version tag for the commit we want to deploy (e.g. v3.6.0)
3. Manually trigger the deployment workflow from the commit

WATcher:
1. PR to main, updating the version
2. PR from main to `deploy` 
3. Deployment runs automatically when there are changes to the `deploy` branch

We think that the CATcher workflow provides more flexibility (and is less troublesome as we only have to PR once, whereas in WATcher we have to PR twice), so we are requesting to change the workflow in WATcher to follow the workflow in CATcher.
</panel>

**Describe the bug**
Playwright Github workflow is failing due to issues with installing playwright in the GitHub runner

**To Reproduce**

https://github.com/CATcher-org/CATcher/actions/runs/12762533496/job/35571190046?pr=1291

**Expected behavior**

<panel type="info" popup-url="https://github.com/CATcher-org/CATcher/issues/1292#issuecomment-2589429732" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**60 :octicon-comment:** (commented on issue #1292)
</div>

%%[created at: 2025 Jan 14 17:32:22]%%

After further investigation, this seems to be a versioning issue, see the following GitHub [thread](https://github.com/microsoft/playwright/issues/30368)

We are using ubuntu-latest in our GitHub runner (i.e. ubuntu 24.04), which is incompatible with the playwright version we are using (i.e. playwright ~1.33).

There are 2 solutions as proposed in the following stack overflow [thread](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/79090211/playwright-tests-in-github-actions-error-for-webkit-with-host-system-is-missing) (as well as in the GitHub thread provided above):
Solution 1: upgrade playwright to v1.48 (or above)
Solution 2: downgrade ubuntu to v22.04

Solution 1 would be a better solution for the long term, but playwright [v1.48](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@playwright/test/v/1.48.2) requires node version >= 18, while CATcher is currently on node v16.x, hence would be more troublesome to upgrade node version
Solution 2 can be easily implemented by specifying the ubuntu version in the GitHub workflow
Hence I would prefer implementing solution2 for the fix


</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 05 01:05:23]%%

The changes required to add a draft PR option in the status field is non-trivial, this is mainly due to the reason that although it seems intuitive that `draft` is a state of its own, the reality is that `draft` is not a state, but an additional boolean `isDraft` field. 

TLDR, a `draft` PR can be either `open` or `closed` state (although in our application logic we only check whether a PR is draft or not when the PR is in open state, creating a sense that draft PRs are always open), hence I don't think it really make sense to add a Draft PR option to our Status filter.

If we really want this option, we should probably add another filter instead
</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 07 13:23:23]%%

Hmm but wouldn't the proposed workflow be problematic as the 2 feature versions are now developed in parallel. 
'''mermaid
gitGraph
    commit id: "Initial commit"
    commit id: "v1.1 starts"
    branch v1.1
    checkout v1.1
    commit id: "Work on v1.1"
    checkout main
    commit id: "v1.2starts"
    branch v1.2
    checkout v1.2
    commit id: "Work on 1.2"
    checkout v1.1
    commit id: "More work on v1.1"
'''
In the above scenario, both feature branches are divergent and changes made to be v1.1 will not be pulled to v1.2 (and when v1.1 eventually gets merged to main, and merged to v1.2, there might be alot of merge conflicts happening and discovered late)

Instead I think we should probably stick to the current workflow, where we create release branches from main when necessary. As the chances of having to work on features in future iterations is low and will likely only happen when we are going to release the current iteration soon.

'''mermaid
gitGraph
    commit id: "Initial commit"
    commit id: "Work on v1.1"
    branch release/v1.1
    checkout release/v1.1
    commit id: "released v1.1"
    checkout main
    commit id: "work on v1.2"
    branch v1.2
    checkout v1.2
    commit id: "More work on v1.1"
'''

Then in the case of patches to the release/v1.1, we should branch out from release/v1.1 and merge the fix to both release/v1.1 and main
</panel>

In my opinion, if the users want to focus on either PRs or Issues, they could filter by type, and if they decide to filter by all (i.e. PRs and Issues), they would probably want to see everything and don't really need the very distinct differentiation between PR and Issue. 

I don't have a good idea on how we can make it distinct and still keep the elegance we have currently. For example we could make the card styling for PRs and Issues very different, but the UI will have a mix of different cards, and that might be slightly weird for me.

Let's see what the others think!

</panel>

<hr class="thick-1 border-secondary" />

<panel type="info" popup-url="https://github.com/CATcher-org/WATcher/issues/444#issuecomment-2739088533" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**79 :octicon-comment:** (commented on issue #444)
</div>

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 20 12:11:36]%%

Good suggestion. This feature does sound like a good to have, we would likely not need to analyse the PR descriptions in our application logic, instead we could change the query used to fetch PRs to also fetch the issues that the PR closes (I quickly searched up and we should be able to use `closingIssuesReferences ` field in PR objects).

However, from the technical side, this increases the difference between the PR objects and Issue Objects, and in our application we are modelling them as the same `Issue` class (although they already have certain differences), so I think we should first do some refactoring to create different models for Issue and PR before we start implementing this change. I think that the refactoring would be non-trivial and might need quite big effort. What do the others think?
</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Feb 08 19:05:49]%%

Extract from `github.service.ts`:
<img width="1122" alt="Image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/0d78e640-5929-47dd-b47c-1be48085f5e9" />

Understand that the current problem is as follows:
When using Github REST api (i.e. `octokit.issues.update` in the example above), we are casting the `response.data` to `GithubIssue`, which is the model for GraphQl GitHub issues. Hence, the value of states attribute is incorrect (`open` instead of `OPEN` and `close` instead of `CLOSE`), and potentially many other attributes too.

Note that this problem is also present in `reopenIssue` and `createIssue`.

> Thus it would be good to standardize this (I would recommend just switching over to GraphQL mutate API instead of using Github REST API to standardize across the application.

This sounds like quite a big change, i.e. we will have to migrate the api calls for these 3 methods to GraphQl, are we sure we want to proceed with this? 

Or do we put in a less risky workaround (i.e. update the states to the correct GraphQl states without changing the api call)?


</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 10 14:38:18]%%

This issue is related to how we are constructing our `Octokit` object, as mentioned in the warning, if we were to use `@octokit/rest` of version >= v17, we would need to add an `authStrategy` option to indicate how we are authenticating (OAuth in our use case). 

Considering that we are able to perform these upgrade now (i.e. `@octokit/rest` to v17 without having to upgrade any other dependencies), I will try to work on this and remove the deprecation warning (so that future upgrades can be performed smoother).
</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 22 20:45:01]%%

Thanks for reporting this issue @Incogdino , indeed a good catch.

After some investigation, I would think that the current behaviour is actually as follows:

1. After marking Issue A as duplicate of Issue B, the assignees will be set the the assignees of Issue B. 
2. After unmarking Issue A as duplicate(i.e. no longer duplicate of Issue B), the assignees are actually remained as assignees of Issue B. (Note that if we went back to the table view at this point, the assignees are not actually reassigned back to the original assignees of Issue A, see the following video for reference)

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/e060f689-4575-4f41-b241-2457a5255a22

However, there is indeed a bug here, where if instead of returning to the table view right after unmarking Issue A as duplicate, the user click on the assignees edit icon, the dropdown shows the original assignees of Issue A, the expected behaviour should be the dropdown showing the assignees of Issue B.

We will look into fixing this issue! Thanks again for reporting.
</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Jan 28 00:30:52]%%

**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
While trying to fix #395 I realised that all predefined filter options are done using magic strings. This makes it hard for me to create a mapping for options to URL encoding.
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/572e1983-f89e-43bd-803f-85e79842e9ff)

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Perhaps it would be a good idea to move all magic strings for filters into enums or constants

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Perhaps an alternative would be to leave it as it is and create a mapping for the encoding using strings with the same value

**Additional context**
I am planning to create a mapping for URL encoding to allow filters when users click `view on github`.
'''TS
const mapping = ``{``
    'open pullrequest' = 'is%3Apr%20AND%20is%3Aopen'
``}``
'''

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 15 02:00:39]%%

**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
While I was working on a new feature, I found testing and understanding the queries and parameters to be hard as we can only change them in code, run them then check the network tab.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
I decided to use Postman to test and try out different queries

Here is a simple example of testing and running using Postman

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/8d253045-4b6c-482a-8435-60c5d6917df0)

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/0750de89-3e18-42e7-95a8-9c34da55883a)

We will be able to test graphql queries first without having to touch any code.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Maybe another solution would be to use [octokit-playground](https://github.com/graphql/graphql-playground) library as we are already using octokit to run the queries

[Github Explorer](https://docs.github.com/en/graphql/overview/explorer) works great too as there is no need for any extra authentication.

**Additional context**
Perhaps having more information for testing and learning might make it easier for other contributors and encourage implementing more complex features using graphql.

Perhaps we can consider
- Postman with a collection of all the queries built-in with variables (reduce the need of having setup queries every time we want to use it)
- Github explorer, easy to use however, every query requires setting up relevant variables

</panel>

**Describe the bug**
Examples for tester response seems to be incorrect [example in user workflow](https://catcher-org.github.io/dg/user-workflow.html), [example in code comments](https://github.com/CATcher-org/CATcher/blob/master/src/app/core/models/templates/tester-response-template.model.ts) and [testing](https://catcher-org.github.io/dg/testing.html)

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:

1. Go to an issue with a 'team's response'
2. Copy example found in [user workflow](https://catcher-org.github.io/dg/user-workflow.html)
3. Issue will be under 'Faulty Issues' in CATcher

**Expected behavior**
Issue should move to 'Issues Pending Response'

**Screenshots**

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c4be251e-9d6c-4d18-8ca6-a97476fc9776)

**Desktop (please complete the following information):**

- OS: Windows 11
- Browser Chrome
- Version 131.0.6778.86

**Additional context**
From further investigation. The issue comes from 'Team chose ['type.DocumentationBug'].' and '**Reason for disagreement:**'.

1. The parser expects ''Team chose ['type.DocumentationBug']' how in the example an additional '.' is supplied.
2. The parser expects '**Reason for disagreement:** ' as seen in [tester response section parser](https://github.com/CATcher-org/CATcher/blob/master/src/app/core/models/templates/section-parsers/tester-response-section-parser.model.ts). However, when directly copied, the additional whitespace at the end is removed.

**Possible solutions**
1. Remove the '.' at the end of the issue descriptions
2. Preserving the white space could be similar to #1273 

Performing the above 2 possible solutions produces the expected results.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c93dece4-2289-443f-9444-5bef2d765597)

Below is the updated example (note whitespace is not copied).
'''
# Team's Response

Description of team's response
# Items for the Tester to Verify
## :question: Issue response

Team chose ['response.Rejected']

- [ ] I disagree

**Reason for disagreement:**
[replace this with your reason]

&lt;catcher-end-of-segment>&lt;hr>
## :question: Issue severity

Team chose ['severity.Low']

Originally ['severity.High']

- [ ] I disagree

**Reason for disagreement:** 
[replace this with your reason]

&lt;catcher-end-of-segment>&lt;hr>
## :question: Issue type

Team chose ['type.DocumentationBug'].

Originally ['type.FunctionalityBug'].

- [ ] I disagree

**Reason for disagreement:**
[replace this with your reason]

&lt;catcher-end-of-segment>&lt;hr>
'''
**Steps to resolving**
- [ ] Fix example in user workflow documentation
- [ ] Fix example in code comments
- [ ] Fix example in testing documentation
</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 19 22:56:16]%%

I think it is a good idea perhaps #408 can take these suggestions into consideration as well! 

By doing a quick check on postman we can actually get reviewers as well by adding a few extra fields I am able to get there reviewers along side the current query that we are using in `FetchPullRequests`. Not sure if adding new fields will generate any additional API calls.

Sample query
```
query FetchPullRequests($owner: String!, $name: String!, $cursor: String) ``{``
  repository(owner: $owner, name: $name) ``{``
    pullRequests(first: 100, after: $cursor) ``{``
      edges ``{``
        cursor
        node ``{``
          ...pullrequest
          isDraft
          labels(first: 100) ``{``
            edges ``{``
              node ``{``
                ...issueLabel
              ``}``
            ``}``
          ``}``
          assignees(first: 100) ``{``
            edges ``{``
              node ``{``
                ...issueAssignee
              ``}``
            ``}``
          ``}``
          reviewRequests(first: 10) ``{``
            nodes ``{``
              requestedReviewer ``{``
                ...requestedReviewerDetails
              ``}``
            ``}``
          ``}``
          reviews(first: 10) ``{``
            nodes ``{``
              author ``{``
                ...reviewAuthor
              ``}``
              state
              submittedAt
            ``}``
          ``}``
        ``}``
      ``}``
    ``}``
  ``}``
``}``
```

Fragments
```
fragment requestedReviewerDetails on User ``{``
  id
  login
  name
  avatarUrl
``}``

fragment reviewAuthor on User ``{``
  id
  login
  name
  avatarUrl
``}``
```

Examples of the reviews section

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/426b21d8-d288-44f8-a948-a93f0d2b944f)

This issue is much more difficult than expected. The main difficulty arises from the fact that models are a class type. The current `filter` is treated as a type `Filter`, that's why `Partial&lt;Filter>` is used without issues when passing into functions such as `FiltersService#updateFilters`. However, this would not be good practice when it is a class `Filter` instead of a type `Filter`. Thus, we need to update all references of `Partial&lt;Filter>`, which is a non-trivial task.

<panel type="warning" popup-url="https://github.com/CATcher-org/WATcher/issues/427" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**51 :octicon-issue-opened:** (created issue #427: Use feature-branches instead of merging to main)
</div>

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 07 11:32:51]%%

As WATcher is nearing its official release cycle, we start to run into the issue where we would like to work on features / issues that are slated for different version releases. 
For example, a developer(s) could be working on a bug fix for the immediate version v1.1 while another developer(s) could be working on a big feature for version v1.2.

Currently, as everything is merged to main, PRs for incremental work done on the feature for version v1.2 are unable to be merged, as it would pollute the main branch.

Hence, I instead propose the use of feature branches like so:

[1] The main branch remains fully working at all times
[2] When a developer wants to start working on the next version, they will branch off main in the upstream repo, following the convention release-v[major].[minor].
[3] When a developer wants to start working on the following versions, in the upstream repo, they can branch off the latest feature branch.
Subsequent updates can be merged into the upstream feature branch.

When it's time for release, a PR can be made from the feature branch to main. Thus, prod can remain to be built from main.


To discuss! Please do suggest alternatives or any opinions you guys might have.
</panel>

</div>

%%[created at: 2025 Feb 22 16:18:14]%%

**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Currently, WATcher is unable to display which PRs have been reviewed or are ready to be merged. It would be useful for users to be able to know which PRs have been reviewed by who. 

**Describe the solution you'd like**
One option for this would be to display the review status and reviewer in the issue-pr-card component. However, the component is already very cluttered, especially when PRs / issues have many labels. 

Another option would be to add the ability to group by reviewers in addition to the current options of milestones and assignees. This might be useful to track the PRs that each team member has reviewed.

Or we could do both by showing just the review status (changes requested / approved / review required) in the issue-pr-card component, and include a group by reviewers option as well.

I personally think adding a group by reviewers functionality would be useful. I would love to hear more suggestions on how to display review statuses without overcrowding the UI.
</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 11 16:41:14]%%

> One suggestion! - We could also consider excluding the test files from our build pipeline, if it is determined that we don't need the js files at all to run the tests. This can complement the test config, so there are two layers of checks to ensure we don''t run duplicated test files.

Thanks @gerteck for the catch! I've looked into this suggestion and excluding the `*.test.ts` files in `tsconfig.json` will indeed compliment the fix. However, there is a small issue with ESLint since it relies on `tsconfig.json` and `packages/core/tsconfig.json` to determine which files to lint. Excluding the test files in `tsconfig.json` would result in ESLint not being able to find those files, leading to errors like:

```
0:0  error  Parsing error: ESLint was configured to run on <tsconfigRootDir>/packages\core\test\unit\Page\filterIconAssets.test.ts using parserOptions.project:
- <tsconfigRootDir>/tsconfig.json
- <tsconfigRootDir>/packages\core\tsconfig.json
However, none of those TSConfigs include this file.
```

To resolve this, I've added new `tsconfig,lint.json` files for ESLint to refer to, ensuring that ESLint can still properly lint the test files while we exclude them from the build pipeline.
</panel>

> The code looks more complicated than what we need for our use-case and i'm not sure if there's some restrictions such that this comment implies we only serve for ipv4?

I took a closer look at this section, which starts from line 308:
'''js
if (LiveServer.logLevel > 2 && address.address === "0.0.0.0") ``{``
  var ifaces = os.networkInterfaces();
  serveURLs = Object.keys(ifaces)
    .map(function(iface) ``{``
      return ifaces[iface];
    ``}``)
    // flatten address data, use only IPv4
    .reduce(function(data, addresses) ``{``
      addresses.filter(function(addr) ``{``
        return addr.family === "IPv4";
      ``}``).forEach(function(addr) ``{``
        data.push(addr);
      ``}``);
      return data;
    ``}``, [])
    .map(function(addr) ``{``
      return protocol + "://" + addr.address + ":" + address.port;
    ``}``);
``}``
'''

This block is some helper code for logging all available addresses when serving on `0.0.0.0`, explicitly listing the URLs users can use to access their MarkBind site. The "IPv4" comment exists because `0.0.0.0` typically only binds to IPv4 addresses, so the logging code filters out IPv6 addresses accordingly. It shouldn't have any impact on the `serve` command's ability to handle IPv6 connections. Also, I believe as of now, our codebase doesn't make use of this logging code anyways since we don't ever set our `LiveServer.logLevel` to above 2.

That said, there is a minor issue:
Since we're now supporting IPv6 addresses, we should also check for the IPv6 equivalent of `0.0.0.0`, which is `::`. Currently, when users serve on `0.0.0.0`, they receive a warning:
'''
WARNING: Using the address '0.0.0.0' could potentially expose your server to the internet, which may pose security risks.
'''
However, no such warning exists for `::`, even though it can have similar implications.

I can add that additional warning for `::` in this PR and update the logging code to also log available IPv6 addresses when users use `::`. Let me know if that sounds good!

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 18 19:55:27]%%

I updated the code here because there was an issue with IPv6 addresses. 

The original code only outputs 1 serveURL message when `serveURL !== openURL`, even if `serveURLs.length > 1` . If a developer tried logging and used an IPv6 zero address like `::0`, the serveURL would be `::0` but the openURL would be `::`. This means that even though there might be multiple addresses used, only 1 will be logged which could be misleading.

For example, before the refactor commit, if a developer set `logLevel > 2` and did `markbind s -a ::`, they would see something like:
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/4435b803-2f65-4ccc-bf9f-5410efbeb446)
All available addresses opened by the zero address are listed out.

But if a developer does a different command like `markbind s -a ::0`, they would instead see:
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/12e1fec1-af46-43ab-9138-f7baecf20357)
I.e. only the address given would be listed, the other addresses opened would not be logged, even though if we check the previous example's URLs, they would work as per normal.

The refactored code just ensures the available addresses are all logged, regardless of whether `serveURL === openURL`. For example, the previous command `markbind s -a ::0` now leads to:
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/caf71d86-e493-40f4-84e7-c67c87da09d9)

Let me know if you'd prefer to keep the original code. If this change seems unnecessary, I'm happy to revert it.
</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 17 13:22:39]%%

As of now, the PR is mostly complete. The only suggestion missing is the reassignment of port. Currently, I'm having issues with figuring out how to do it.

Unlike the reassignment of `host` where we give a default value to use, we are currently relying on `.listen(0)` to give us a random available port. This port value is only available after the server completes the `.listen()` execution. One possible way to reassign right after is to use a callback during `listen()`, like:

'''js
server.listen(0, host, () => ``{``
  port = server.address().port;
``}``);
'''

However, from my own testing, this reassignment tends to come _after_ the `listening` event is emitted. This means the listener for `listening` at line 297 will still use the previous `port` value, rather than the reassigned one, defeating the purpose of this reassignment change.

If anyone is more familiar with the `http` module, `listen()` or the scheduling between the callback and the event emitting, feel free to look into this!
</panel>

1. The `if` condition is False, so it moves on to the `else-if`
2. The `else-if` condition is True, so it continues with `cheerio(node).append(getButtonHTML());`

However, in the new code, the same scenario will instead:
1. The `if` condition is True, so it moves on into the inner code
2. The inner `if` condition is False, so it doesn't continue
3. The `else-if` condition is never checked since the `if` condition already passed.

The new code would result in `cheerio(node).append(getButtonHTML());` not being executed, while it would have been executed by the old code. Will this be a possible issue? Or is such a scenario impossible to begin with?
</panel>

  ].join('\n');

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 01 18:43:49]%%

### Please confirm that you have searched existing issues in the repo

Yes, I have searched the existing issues

### Any related issues?

_No response_

### Tell us about your environment

Windows 10

### MarkBind version

5.5.3

### Describe the bug and the steps to reproduce it

When IPv6 addresses are provided for the `serve` command, the URL opened for live preview is an invalid one. This often leads to an error pop-up, which may mislead users to believe that the address they provided was invalid. In reality, it was the live preview URL that was invalid.

For example, `markbind serve -a ::1` will attempt to launch the URL "http://::1:8080". The proper URL for this address is actually "http://[::1]:8080/", i.e. the IPv6 address is enclosed in square brackets.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d1a36758-c1ff-405c-847a-25a022df4514)

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/ebcb7e2b-3f7d-470c-8d75-e8ec7fac31d0)

There's currently a workaround which is to add the square brackets within the `serve` command, however this is unintuitive for users.

### Expected behavior

When an IPv6 address is specified, the URL launched for live preview automatically appends the square brackets, leading to a valid link.

For example, the command `markbind serve -a ::1` should lead to the following page:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/b7f52fbd-59ce-4183-8194-38e98477ff8b)

### Anything else?

_No response_
</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 17 13:45:30]%%

### Please confirm that you have searched existing issues in the repo

Yes, I have searched the existing issues

### Any related issues?

_No response_

### Tell us about your environment

Windows 11

### MarkBind version

5.6.0

### Describe the bug and the steps to reproduce it

Currently, there's a warning for the user when they try to serve on address `0.0.0.0`. However, when the IPv6 zero address (`::`) is used there is no such warning, even though it would have the same security risks.

For e.g.:
- `markbind s -a 0.0.0.0` would result in the following warning:
   `WARNING: Using the address '0.0.0.0' could potentially expose your server to the internet, which may pose security risks. Proceed with caution? [y/N]`
- `markbind s -a ::` would not result in any warning at all, even though it also exposes the server to the internet.

The issue lies with the following code:
'''js
function isIPAddressZero(address) ``{``
  const patternForZero = /&hat;0(\.0)*$/;

  return patternForZero.test(address);
``}``
'''

There is currently no regex/check for IPv6's zero address, that's why the warning doesn't appear.

### Expected behavior

When users try to serve on the IPv6 zero address, they should be appropriately warned about the security risks involved, similar to how we do it for `0.0.0.0`.

### Anything else?

_No response_
</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 21 12:09:43]%%

### Please confirm that you have searched existing issues in the repo

Yes, I have searched the existing issues

### Any related issues?

#1755

### Tell us about your environment

Windows 10

### MarkBind version

5.6.0

### Describe the bug and the steps to reproduce it

As discussed in PR #2656 with @tlylt and @lhw-1, it is possible to get false positive from the code coverage report generated by Codecov after merging a PR to `master` (see commit d1ba064 in `master` branch or the [Codecov report](https://app.codecov.io/gh/MarkBind/markbind/commit/d1ba06439c4d94c15c20ec97db13cc32c53b7542) for an example of a false positive). Currently, this false positive scenario is not mentioned in the developer docs but will be updated in PR #2659.

There is currently no strict requirement to maintain code coverage before merging PRs. Instead, the Codecov report is meant to be used during PR review to evaluate if the PR severely degrades the coverage.

However, the Codecov report doesn't seem to be working reliably in the PRs, where they stop reporting the status for some PRs. For e.g. in PR #2656, the following error occurs during CI:
```
[2025-03-20T12:23:00.740Z] ['info'] Pinging Codecov: https://codecov.io/upload/v4?package=github-action-3.1.6-uploader-0.8.0&token=*******&branch=serve-codecov-hotfix&build=13969151105&build_url=https%3A%2F%2Fgithub.com%2FMarkBind%2Fmarkbind%2Factions%2Fruns%2F13969151105&commit=d63ce9f4dc7cdd74673506b9ae88ae525639362d&job=CI&pr=2656&service=github-actions&slug=MarkBind%2Fmarkbind&name=&tag=&flags=&parent=
[2025-03-20T12:23:00.965Z] ['error'] There was an error running the uploader: Error uploading to [https://codecov.io:](https://codecov.io/) Error: There was an error fetching the storage URL during POST: 429 - ``{``"message":"Rate limit reached. Please upload with the Codecov repository upload token to resolve issue. Expected time to availability: 1549s."``}``
```

This error is preventing our ability to properly review PRs and their code coverage changes. As discovered by @tlylt, it seems that raising the PR from a fork leads to a more serious rate limit on the Codecov tokens, leading to the error. (Reference: https://github.com/codecov/feedback/issues/301)

The suggestion mentioned in the issue is something like our dual workflow that we have documented in https://github.com/MarkBind/markbind-action/tree/master/.github/workflows#usage for security reason, which might need some effort to understand and implement.

Let's take a closer look at Codecov to see how to reliably generate the report for each PR.

### Expected behavior

Codecov bot reliably generates a Codecov report for each PR every CI run. This will allow PR reviewers to properly analyze the code coverage changes introduced by the PR and highlight any serious degradation.

### Anything else?

_No response_
</panel>

<panel type="info" popup-url="https://github.com/MarkBind/markbind/issues/2658#issuecomment-2743033390" expanded>

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 21 19:03:36]%%

Migrating to Codecov v5 might resolve this issue. According to their [release notes](https://github.com/codecov/codecov-action/releases/tag/v5.0.0): 
> The `v5` release also coincides with the opt-out feature for tokens for public repositories. In the `Global Upload Token` section of the settings page of an organization in codecov.io, you can set the ability for Codecov to receive a coverage reports from any source. This will allow contributors or other members of a repository to upload without needing access to the Codecov token. For more details see [how to upload without a token](https://docs.codecov.com/docs/codecov-tokens#uploading-without-a-token).

If we enable this setting, PRs from forks should no longer be impacted by the rate limits on Codecov tokens, allowing code coverage reports to be generated reliably. Would this be a viable solution for us?

\end``{``equation``}``

\begin``{``equation``}``
  \begin``{``pmatrix``}``
    A & B \\ B & C
  \end``{``pmatrix``}``
  \textit``{``Test``}``
\end``{``equation``}``

\begin``{``equation``}``
E = mc&hat;2, \quad a&hat;2 + b&hat;2 = c&hat;2, \quad \sum_``{``n=1``}``&hat;``{``\infty``}`` \frac``{``1``}````{``n&hat;2``}`` = \frac``{``\pi&hat;2``}````{``6``}``
\end``{``equation``}``

\begin``{``equation``}``
f(x) = ax&hat;2 + bx + c
\end``{``equation``}``
```
| With font files | Without font files |
| --------------- | ------------------- |
| ![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/a2188e88-9eb3-4102-b165-8f8d63f33c36) | ![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/8e2fc79b-d3b9-483a-a539-acb7011f25d9) |
Notice the difference in the matrix and Sigma, as well as some minor differences in the other text and notation.

### Possible Reason

After some investigation, it seems that the issue is most likely during the build process. When a user does `serve` or `build`, the `fonts` folder that holds the KaTeX fonts is placed inside the `css` folder, i.e. `_site\markbind\css\fonts`. 

The file `markbind.min.css` is attempting to access the fonts but is using the wrong relative path to it. That is because within our own `core-web` package, the original path was `packages\core-web\dist\css\markbind.min.css` and the path to the fonts folder was `packages\core-web\dist\fonts`. Because of this, `markbind.min.css` references the fonts using the path `../font_name`


![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/4dd190d1-7226-451a-8fdd-6df72fe2fbe9)

This means that after the site is built, rather than accessing the font folder properly, `markbind.min.css` is trying to access `_site\markbind\fonts\font_name`, which doesn't exist. This leads to the errors we see in the console. Manually moving the fonts folder out to `_site\markbind` and reloading the page seems to fix the issue.

### Expected behavior

The KaTeX files should be loaded in properly without any issues, resulting in the correct looking text font used for KaTeX notation.

If what I've identified is the actual root cause, then we only need to make sure that the relative path referenced by `markbind.min.css` is correctly set for the fonts. This is either done by adjusting our own `core-web` package or by adjusting the `fonts` folder for the built site.

### Anything else?

_No response_

### What is the area that this feature belongs to?

Reader Usability

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.

**Current behavior:**
When a reader clicks a footnote link, the page scrolls down to the corresponding footnote content at the bottom of the page. However, there is no link to take the reader back to where that footnote was mentioned in the main text.

**Why this is an issue:**
- Readers may not realize they can use their browser's back button to return to the reference since it may not be obvious or intuitive
- It's also difficult for readers to locate where a particular footnote is reference if they're browsing the footnotes directly. For example, it's not easy for readers to tell where the 4th footnote ("Math") was mentioned without scrolling through or using `ctrl-F`:
  
  ![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/014f2485-c989-4e9f-befc-f2c2dfea82b1)

### Describe the solution you'd like

Add a "back to reference" link, e.g. ``, next to each footnote at the bottom of the page. This link would scroll the reader back to the original spot in the page where that footnote was referenced.

An example we could follow is GFMD's footnotes:
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d9f28b08-dcff-4b35-b4bb-760f4248af76)

This would improve navigation and make the reading experience smoother and more intuitive, especially for long reference-heavy documents that MarkBind caters to.

After some investigation, the error during CLI testing appears to be intentional. Firstly, the error message comes from the implementation of the `src` attribute for popover elements. This behavior was introduced in PR #1780. The purpose of the error was to prevent URLs like "https://www.google.com/" from being used in the `src` attribute.

The specific test code triggering the error is as follows:
```
<popover header="URLs are not valid" src="http://www.shouldnotwork.com">
  URLs should not be valid
</popover>
```

This popover deliberately triggers the error and the snapshot test expects the popover's HTML content to be replaced with an error message like this:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/6c99dd13-2161-4940-9786-88ffa5d70875)


I do agree that the error is misleading though. The CLI tests do not verify if the error is properly logged, so perhaps we can switch from logging this as an error to logging it as a warning instead. 

Users will still be notified and developers can ignore the warnings during testing. A PR could also be created to improve the error message since the current one is not user-friendly anyways.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/dad0e514-79f9-4512-88a4-a6cbde325fd8)


EDIT:
I've made another suggestion for a fix in PR #2639 that logs the error as a warning for developers during testing but logs it as an error for users.

I haven't looked into the core package tests yet but I suspect the errors (at least those in the screenshots) are also from the same file and a similar fix can be applied to them as well.

> Thank you for spotting the vue hydration issue. It indeed resolved the "[Vue warn]"
> 
> I can't really remember why I put there a haha. I now see that this creates a mismatch between server and client templates?

yep! I think the issue is that the [`&lt;span>`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/span) can only contain permitted [phrasing content](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Content_categories#phrasing_content) (text and markup only), so when the web browser receives the rendered HTML it does some reordering of some sort to reorder the invalid HTML into something valid which in turn causes the mismatch between rendered DOM and received HTML. 

I also just pushed the update to the snapshot files (to account for `&lt;span>` removal) and the unit test (removed check for v-dataTable Vue directive) for the DataTables. Testing for `dt-processed` in the unit tests and rendering of dataTables might be more complex as that requires integration testing with the dataTable js file.

Thanks @Tim-Siu for your speedy reply!!

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 12 13:06:15]%%

To set some context - from what I understand in differences between `createApp()` and `createSSRApp()` is whether the app runs in `hydration mode` when first mounted. Reference: [Vue docs](https://vuejs.org/guide/scaling-up/ssr.html#rendering-an-app)
> To make the client-side app interactive, Vue needs to perform the hydration step. During hydration, it creates the same Vue application that was run on the server, matches each component to the DOM nodes it should control, and attaches DOM event listeners.
> To mount an app in hydration mode, we need to use [createSSRApp()](https://vuejs.org/api/application#createssrapp) instead of createApp():

This code snippet is run client side - `index.js` is the entry point for the markbind binary that is bundled in `core-web`. Since it is clientSide - definitely should be using `CreateSSRApp()` - as the client is also served the `*.html` that was pre-rendered, and we want the client to do hydration and check differences betweeen served `html` and DOM structure given by the render function. 

* Client is referring to the web browser serving the page

--- 

A related question is whether we should be calling `createApp()` or `createSSRApp()` when we render the `html` in the server. (that is to be sent to client). Referring to this portion in `PageVueServerRenderer`:

https://github.com/gerteck/markbind/blob/7ea3d6d544e7b0d3b69333f2d88279d793d67da5/packages/core/src/Page/PageVueServerRenderer.ts#L88-L103

Theoretically, it should be fine to use `createApp()` on server to render HTML since there's no hydration involved, but I couldn't find any information on this. Following the [serverRenderer (renderToString) npm usage docs](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@vue/server-renderer), it seems that `renderToString` is supposed to be used with `createSSRApp()` so there is that. 

</panel>

To set the context, In the current logic, the only way for the `questions` array to be defined is if the quiz was a parent component and initialized the questions array. So the quiz being undefined is used in the logic to check whether it was in a quiz or not.

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/306cb047-15f1-49ca-ab58-020d6f72bdc4)

To elaborate specifically why, the quiz would `provide` a defined array [], so if our `injected` question was defined, it must mean that the question is in a parent quiz component.

https://github.com/MarkBind/markbind/blob/ea7cf57e067f0880d470265fad2fae8a0d3eaa24/packages/vue-components/src/questions/Quiz.vue#L116-L130

This affects the logic in the snippet in previous comment. If we define the default value of the questions array to be a defined, but empty array. The question is pushed into the `questions` array (through [provide/inject](https://vuejs.org/guide/components/provide-inject) by Quiz), because it thinks it is a parent Quiz component.  At the same time, it hides the question** as well. (To be shown by the quiz component as per quiz logic later)

https://github.com/MarkBind/markbind/blob/ea7cf57e067f0880d470265fad2fae8a0d3eaa24/packages/vue-components/src/questions/QuizQuestionMixin.js#L44-L49

'''js
 created() ``{`` 
   if (this.questions) ``{``               // thinks it is in a quiz
     this.active = false;              // hides the question
     this.questions.push(this);   // adds this question in the array
   ``}`` 
 ``}``, 
'''

This raises some issues because some methods in `question.vue` uses the property of whether `questions` is defined to determine if it is in the quiz. I think it could be refactored to make it more clear and have proper methods as this is logical dependency is not so clear at first (or second) glance.

https://github.com/MarkBind/markbind/blob/ea7cf57e067f0880d470265fad2fae8a0d3eaa24/packages/vue-components/src/questions/Question.vue#L150-L163

However, a more relevant issue is that I don't think it resolves the hydration issue. I noted that the reason why the hydration error doesn't show up is because if we set `questions:` `default: []`, as per the logic in `created()` above is because it hides the question. `active=false`. Specifically this causes the whole question to not render (`v-if=active`):

https://github.com/MarkBind/markbind/blob/ea7cf57e067f0880d470265fad2fae8a0d3eaa24/packages/vue-components/src/questions/Question.vue#L1-L3

 But actually if we set it back to `active=true` actually the hydration error still persists even if `questions` array is defined..

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 12 13:21:24]%%

> @gerteck great work  Just started playing around with the deployed site to check for any defects. One minor thing I noticed when comparing against https://markbind-master.netlify.app/
> 
> * The quiz's next icon animates from the top left to bottom right when clicked.


Thank you for your help on this PR! I also noted that [popovers](https://deploy-preview-2622--markbind-master.netlify.app/userguide/components/popups#popovers) also lost their spacing:

![Picture1](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d89473dd-5c3f-4c6d-a77c-6d326f6e525e)

It's could be because the vue component libraries were updated or some differences in the configuration syntax, since I made minimal changes enough just to satisfy any errors and warnings.

After investigation, I have found that this is because of whitespace preservation in the rendering of the HTML.

```
<button class="btn btn-secondary">Popover on top</button>
<button class="btn btn-secondary">Popover on top</button>
<button class="btn btn-secondary">Popover on top</button>
```
The gaps between each button is a result of the newline being parsed as whitespace between each button. However, Vue 3 automatically condenses and removes this whitespace, causing the resulting removal of the gap.

```
app.config.compilerOptions.whitespace = 'preserve';
```

This will be added during the rendering process on server side to restore previous Vue 2 default behavior.

</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 15 15:16:12]%%

> One issue I noticed: 2nd level drop-down menus do not disappear as they should

* Identified issue dropdown submenus do not disappear due to [breaking change in Vue 3](https://v3-migration.vuejs.org/breaking-changes/children): The $children instance property has been removed from Vue 3.0 and is no longer supported.
* This caused the current logic that hides submenus at the same level to break, as it was reliant on the `$children` property to do so.
* I have made a non-trivial change, to maintain the logic to hide other submenu instances at the same level, by shifting from the use of `$children` to maintaining a list of submenus at each level using `provide/inject` to resolve this issue.

</panel>

> Some more issues I noticed on the rendered site:
> 
> * The tree diagram functionality is no longer working:
>   
> * Modal opening animation is gone (before: a smooth transition to the opened modal, now: immediate opening of modal window)

I have looked into the tree diagram functionality: The root cause is due to changing of default handling of whitespaces from Vue 2 to Vue 3, specifically: [https://vuejs.org/api/application.html#app-config-compileroptions-whitespace](https://vuejs.org/api/application.html#app-config-compileroptions-whitespace)
* default in Vue 2 is to preserve, changed to condense in Vue 3.

A few ways we can approach this to resolve the issue.
* set default option to `preserve` for the Vue app in render function generation, rendering and mounting
* transform tree element to `&lt;pre class="tree"/>`, as `&lt;pre/>` use case is to preserve all whitespaces
* do both.

Will investigate modal opening animation soon alongside that of quiz button animation
</panel>

I couldn't find a way to disable the warnings for server-renderer meaningfully. However, the warning does point out a legitimate issue though  the HTML generated by the All Contributors bot has unescaped quotes in the alt attribute:
```
<img src="URL" width="100px;" alt="Shuyao "Tim" Xu"/>
```
The issue is occuring because the inner quotes around are not escaped (i.e., should be `&quot;`). Causing the html to be recognised as `alt = "Shuyao "` and `Tim` and `Xu"`. The error in the code isn't generated by vue renderer, but rather the all-contributors bot. 

https://github.com/MarkBind/markbind/blob/ea7cf57e067f0880d470265fad2fae8a0d3eaa24/docs/about.md?plain=1#L133


Since this is an edge case, maybe instead we can open a small PR to manually escape the quotes in about.md (i.e., alt="Shuyao `&quot;`Tim`&quot;` Xu"). Also, maybe file a PR or issue upstream with the All Contributors project to raise concern on handling alt attributes with quotes.

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 22 12:42:15]%%

I have investigated and identified the cause of regression for site-nav and page-nav whitespace. 

This was due to a change in `portal-vue` rendering mechanism, specifically [portal-target no longer rendering a root element](https://portal-vue.linusb.org/guide/migration.html#portaltarget-component)
* A high-level explanation - Due to this expectation, the style attribute accounting for the `--sticky-header-height` was applied twice, causing this whitespace.
* Fix: applied a parent div to `portal-target` to 'absorb' this styling to maintain the expectation as per `vue-portal` v2. I have also done a rough check for other components that use portal-vue if such fix is required, but not needed as their styling is not affected as per a preliminary check.

* We can consider refactoring this in the future.  However, note that the change to refactor is not too trivial and requires some significant understanding of current styling in `main.css`, with regards to `#page-nav` and `#site-nav`, and how it interacts with `Overlay`, `OverlaySource`, and `portal-vue`.


</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 24 12:30:17]%%

Just Pushed a fix for the `closeable` directive.

I initially updated the directive's `bind()` hook to `beforeMount()` based on the [official Vue migration guide](https://v3-migration.vuejs.org/breaking-changes/custom-directives.html). However, this change caused the directive to stop working correctly  since the DOM mutations need to happen after the element is mounted.

I've now fixed this by updating the hook from beforeMount() to mounted(), ensuring all DOM manipulations and event bindings happen after the element is fully available in the DOM.

The `closeable` directive works now: https://deploy-preview-2622--markbind-master.netlify.app/userguide/reusingcontents#allowing-users-to-remove-some-contents
</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 29 16:31:53]%%

For anyone who wants to understand the latest commit (and preceeding commit):

![pic](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/bd62ae38-6174-4716-b323-4d68237aebb3)

The pictures did not resize and defaulted to max size was because the method to set height and width was not firing, which were set to fire on `load` event. It did not fire on Vue 3 hydration, but did so for Vue 2.

The reason the load event fired in Vue 2 but not in Vue 3 is likely due to a difference in hydration behavior between Vue 2 and Vue 3 during SSR (Server-Side Rendering). In short, it seems like:
* Vue 2: load event fired after hydration of DOM.
* Vue 3: likely the onload event is fired before Vue runs and hydrates the DOM.

This seems to be a somewhat known (?) issue through search.

It could be that that when the component is hydrated in Vue 3, the image is already in the DOM and is marked as loaded and not fire `load` event for performance reasons. Or that Vue 2 retriggers the load event etc. I dont know the exact reason.

[Load Event](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/load_event)

What Ive done is to add a `mounted` routine to run the height and width calculation and setting if the image is already loaded, to be sure that it runs in any case.

This `@load` listener is also used in `Annotate`, `Thumbnail`, so I will check it and push changes if needed as well
Thumbnail also visibly has this issue (sizing inside the thumbnail):  
* Left is Vue 3, Right is Vue 2 (has since been updated to be as per right image).
* The thumbnail is not resizing to fit the size attribute, also because `load` is not being fired.

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/a99c72f5-d4ca-4afe-99ce-497ac47a09d5)

Thumbnails now fixed:

* https://deploy-preview-2622--markbind-master.netlify.app/userguide/components/imagesanddiagrams#thumbnails

Sizing of pics also now fixed:

* https://gerteck.github.io/cs2103-website/schedule/week10/topics.html#command-pattern

</panel>

*  directly use mermaid.js to render 'mermaid' elements? (wouldn't need to attach it to window object). The [default built-in behaviour](https://mermaid.js.org/config/usage.html#using-mermaid-run) is such that mermaid just renders all elements with 'class="mermaid"' automatically.
* use  '&lt;pre class="mermaid"> XXX &lt;/pre>' format for transformation. '&lt;pre>' HTML element is the [standard](https://mermaid.js.org/config/usage.html#installing-and-hosting-mermaid-on-a-webpage) usage for mermaid on their website, and as a bonus, that flash before rendering also preserves the original textual presentation of the mermaid diagram. I think it looks better too. It also better aligns if users want to directly use that in their markdown file. 
* Similar logic, conditionally import mermaid only if mermaid elements are found.

After discussion last week, I realized that if we can get a fully functional search bar that does a full text search, it would probably be a better idea to just do away with the index/header search, since it was a placeholder from the start.

I found an interesting adaption of Pagefind in a very similar fashion to Algolia, see here
* https://www.npmjs.com/package/vitepress-plugin-pagefind?activeTab=readme
* https://vue-command-palette.robertshaw.id/ 

Using the vue command palette package, it would not be too hard to recreate the algolia UI [sample implementation here](https://sugarat.top/) (open source chinese blog, can do ctrl + k to open command palette, search "test") and effectively replace the current search bar with that. 

However, the issue is that these packages are all in Vue 3 making it incompatible with the current Vue2 library. I think it may be time to tackle the Vue 2 -&gt; Vue 3 migration for greater longevity of the current components and future new components if developed 
</panel>

I think the logic here could be a bit clearer. I think it could be optimized to be easier to follow. 

 1. Perhaps consider storing `immediateHighlight` in a separate variable instead of mutating `str` and returning it? This could make the logic much clearer to understand, e.g. something like
```
// FOR REFERENCE ONLY idk if it directly works
const immediateHighlight = highlightRules.find((rule) => ``{``
  return rule.getHighlightType(currentLineNumber).some((``{`` highlightType, color ``}``) => ``{``
    if (highlightType === HIGHLIGHT_TYPES.WholeLine) ``{``
      return Highlighter.highlightWholeLine(line, color);
    ``}``
    if (highlightType === HIGHLIGHT_TYPES.WholeText) ``{``
      return Highlighter.highlightWholeText(line, color);
    ``}``
    return false;
  ``}``);
``}``);

if (immediateHighlight) ``{``
  return immediateHighlight;
``}``

%%[created at: 2025 Feb 07 03:15:52]%%

### Any related issues?

#2084 Vue Migration Investigation

Others: 
* #1702 Bootstrap 5
* #1536 scopedSlots depreciation

## Vue Migration Vue 2 to Vue 3

MarkBind (v5.5.3) is currently using Vue 2. Vue2 has reached EOL, (end-2023) and will not receive any type of support. Packages supporting Vue2 used may not be maintained by extension. This limits the extensibility and maintainability of MarkBind, especially the vue-components package. (UI Library Package).

Vue3 has TypeScript support, noticeable performance improvements and more responsive application. Also has smaller bundle size. Do note that  Vue 3 does not support IE13 (internet explorer).  Note that the migration is a time intensive process with codebase understanding required. Currently, MarkBind Vue components are authored in the Vue Options API style. While migrating to Vue 3, we should continue to use this API style. Future work can consider cost benefit of switching to using Composition API.

[Breaking changes](https://v3-migration.vuejs.org/breaking-changes/) to expect include: breaking Vue framework API changes, different dependencies used for Vue 2 vs Vue 3, SSR.

Intricate understanding of both Vue 2, Vue 3, low-level dependency APIs and MarkBind (in particular with regards to SSR, Hydrating, Bundling) is needed to conduct this. Some relevant links to understanding / reviewing the PR:
* [Vue 3 API Reference](https://vuejs.org/api/application.html#createapp)
* [Vue SFC](https://vuejs.org/guide/scaling-up/sfc.html)
* [Vue Rendering Mechanism](https://vuejs.org/guide/extras/rendering-mechanism)
* [Vue Migration Build](https://v3-migration.vuejs.org/migration-build)
* [@vue/compiler-sfc](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@vue/compiler-sfc)
* [@vue/server-renderer](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@vue/server-renderer)

Additionally, here are some relevant documentation of the codebase I have written and compiled to speed up the understanding process for purpose of peer development/review.
* [pageVueServerRenderer](https://gerteck.github.io/mb-architecture/contents/core/pageVueServerRenderer.html)
* [Core-Web Package](https://gerteck.github.io/mb-architecture/contents/core-web/core-web.html)
* [Vue-Components](https://gerteck.github.io/mb-architecture/contents/vue/vueComponents.html)

## Work To-Do

### **Compilation and SSR of Vue (Core):**

`Page/PageVueServerRenderer.ts` needs to be updated
1. [x] 'vue-template-compiler' has been replaced by '@vue/compiler-sfc', hence`compileVuePageAndCreateScript` method which compiles page into Vue Application to get the render function must be updated. For Vue 3, the way the render function is created and consumed is different. Do this without disabling SSR.
2. [x] `renderVuePage`: Method that Renders Vue page app into html string (Vue SSR). Ensure that it works during migration process. Updated to use `@vue/server-render` package for Vue3
3. [x] Ensure no regressions, do testing etc.

### **Webpack bundling (Core-Web)**
`Core-Web` library needs to be updated
1. [x] Update `core-web/src/index.js` setup() process. Ensure setup functions for mounting Vue apps are not affected. Updated to use new Vue `app instance` setup API.
2. [x] Update `vue-loader` package
3. [x] Update webpack configurations if relevant.
4. [x] Ensure bundling no regressions, (to do after refactoring vue components) 
5. [x] `VueCommonAppFactory.js`.The appFactory helps create the Vue app instances needed for each page, to set up the necessary configurations. Configure it if necessary for Vue 3, and adapt if needed for compatibility with Vue3 components

### **Vue Components SFCs**
Vue-Components Library needs to be updated
- [x] Update vue-components SFCs.
- [x] Update dependencies and librarie used
Note: Vue 2 Options API -&gt; Vue 3 Options API should not have too many changes. Should be the most straightforward process. However, a lot of dependencies have to be updated such as `floating vue`, etc. 
- [x] Ensure no regressions as in https://github.com/MarkBind/markbind/issues/1519

### **Vue Testing**
Update all testing packages and dependencies
- [x] Update testing dependencies for Vue 3
- [x] Update tests (to be done after vue components refactoring)

### **Plugins:**
Update necessary plugins (change in Vue directive API)
1.  [x] Ensure usability and non-regression of `dataTable` plugin as Vue Directive used.
2.  [x] Ensure usability and non-regression of `Mermaid` plugins as Vue Directive used.


## Relevant Changelog Vue2 to Vue3:  (FYI)
> Global Mounting: Vue.js 2: The global Vue instance is used to mount the root component. Vue.js 3: Introduces createApp for creating the application instance and makes the mounting process more explicit.

| Feature              | Vue 2                          | Vue 3                          |
|----------------------|--------------------------------|--------------------------------|
| Instance Creation    | `new Vue()`                    | `createApp()`                  |
| Global Configuration | On Vue constructor             | On app instance                |
| Global APIs          | Attached to Vue                 | Instance methods on app        |
| Reactivity System    | `Object.defineProperty`        | `Proxy`                        |
| Composition API      | Not available                  | Available                      |
| Fragments            | Single root element required   | Multiple root elements allowed |
| Teleport             | Not available                  | Built-in `&lt;teleport>` support  |

* In Vue 2, plugins add global level functionality. In Vue 3, each `createApp` call creates completely isolated app instance with its own config and global properties. Due to differences, the Vue instance is setup differently.
* Migrating from `new Vue` to createSSRApp(): case study [here](https://v3.ru.vuejs.org/guide/render-function.html) on using render function
* In Vue2, static render functions explicitly separated from main render function, but in Vue3, it is not. Hence, only one render function. (`compileVuePageAndCreateScript`)
* package `vue-server-renderer` is for Vue 2.0. Corresponding functionality for Vue 3 is in `@vue/server-renderer`, which is actually a dependency of the main `vue` package.


>  Custom Directives: Vue.js 2: Custom directives are registered globally using Vue.directive. Vue.js 3: Custom directives are registered using the app.directive method, making it more modular and scoped to the app instance.


## FAQ
- What about considering letting vue2 and vue3 co-exist? 
We can use a migration build (Vue 2.7) that allows both Vue 2 & 3 code in a single codebase. Once done, migrate over to Vue 3.  However, I faced some issues with getting `@vue/compat` to work.

### **Some other sources:** 
- [Migration QA](https://www.monterail.com/blog/vue-3-migration-qa)
- [Vue2-Vue3 Differences](https://blog.shiftasia.com/difference-between-vuejs-2-and-3-when-to-use-them/)
- [Official Migration Guide](https://v3-migration.vuejs.org/migration-build.html)

> Regarding [#2475](https://github.com/MarkBind/markbind/pull/2475) and [#2446](https://github.com/MarkBind/markbind/pull/2446)
> 
> There seems to be a good documentation on [Vue migration guide; custom directives](https://v3-migration.vuejs.org/breaking-changes/custom-directives.html) API changes on custom directives.
> 
> Based on my understanding, we need to
> 
> 1. Add instance creation with `const app = Vue.createApp(``{````}``)`
> 2. Migrate from using `inserted` to `mounted`.

Realized it takes a bit more than that. In Vue 2, custom directives are registered globally using `Vue.directive`. However, in Vue , custom directives are registered using the `app.directive` method, making it more modular and scoped to the app instance. 

This means that we can't just grab the global Vue instance and install the directive. We would have to register the directive on the current Vue instance we are using to render the page, before rendering or hydrating. 

Maybe will consider 
#2548 Support Mermaid Diagrams in Offline Mode
#2529 Make Mermaid, Datatables Default
since the overhaul is going to be necessary.

%%[created at: 2025 Feb 25 23:46:52]%%

I think we could consider different implementations to make this work

## Alternative Implementations
### Mount Multiple Vue instance for each Mermaid Element
This is alternative to attaching the directive to parent app Vue instance.  Initializing a new vue instance for each Mermaid diagram, registering the mermaid directive for that specific instance.
Ensures that each diagram has its own scoped configuration and avoids issues with Vue 3's global app instance limitations. However, this could lead to performance overhead if many Mermaid diagrams are rendered on a page. (Unsure)

### Direct Mutation of Mermaid Elements
Directly mutate Mermaid elements outside of Vues reactive. Could involve simply manipulating the DOM and invoking Mermaids rendering functions manually on element. Since the mermaid script runs after html is hydrated by Vue, on client side. 

## Plugin vs. Default Features

Making it a plugin vs. default feature: I think if we make it default there are definitely size and performance impacts, thank you for pointing it out, overlooked this crucial aspect.

Considering this, I think it definitely makes sense to keep these features as plugins.

### Difference in size / performance

A quick test on [markbind.org](https://markbind.org/) shows 
(`dev tools` -&gt; `sources` -&gt; `plugins/dataTable/datatables.min.js` || `mermaid-5a5980d4.js` or record network )
* mermaid.js file to be at 322kb, 
* datatable.js + css file at 192kb
(actual sizes after compression are 102+62kB)
 
which is actually quite hefty. E.g. if you load markbind.org, you need to process(~0.5 mb) of just the plugin `js` scripts even if no datatable or mermaid element on current page.

**Potential Fix to complement trade-off of offline support and dynamic loading**:
One quick way I can think of is that perhaps we can provide a toggle through plugin context to toggle between offline support (bundling js file) and dynamic online importing - what do you think?

</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 08 00:51:19]%%

### Please confirm that you have searched existing issues in the repo

Yes, I have searched the existing issues

### Any related issues?

Previous PRs on these Plugins for reference: #1043 #1668

### Tell us about your environment

Win 11

### MarkBind version

5.5.3

### Describe the bug and the steps to reproduce it

The codeBlockCopyButtons.ts and codeBlockWrapButtons.ts plugins introduce unwanted side effects.

See:

https://github.com/MarkBind/markbind/blob/2cadb784fb53f6135ddd070056190142b50dc6d4/packages/core/src/plugins/codeBlockCopyButtons.ts#L67-L76

https://github.com/MarkBind/markbind/blob/2cadb784fb53f6135ddd070056190142b50dc6d4/packages/core/src/plugins/codeBlockWrapButtons.ts#L51-L60

Both plugins process all `&lt;pre>` nodes and insert copy and wrap buttons to `&lt;pre>` elements if enabled, no matter if it contains `&lt;code>` or not. 

For some context, note that `markdown-it` follows the [CommonMark spec](https://spec.commonmark.org/0.31.2/#fenced-code-blocks), and processes triple backticks into (''') into `&lt;pre/>` and `&lt;code>`.  For example, in the first code block below, this code snippet that we might  write in markdown file, gets converted to the following in html on the web page (second code block):

'''md
'''js
console.log("Hello, world!");
'''
'''
 
'''html
&lt;pre>&lt;code class="language-js">console.log("Hello, world!");&lt;/code>&lt;/pre>
'''
We should minimize the side effect by only appending/inserting these code-copy or code-wrap buttons if we find `&lt;code>` in the `&lt;pre>` element. 

Why is this not just a trivial issue? The [`&lt;pre>` (preformatted text)](https://www.w3schools.com/TAgs/tag_pre.asp) element is used to display text exactly as is written in HTML code, preserving spaces, line breaks and indentation. If any user wants to use this element, as per `HTML` specifications, they will incur this side effect if they have the plugin enabled. (- MarkBind should support `HTML`)

This also may have other unexpected effects on other components that use `&lt;pre>` to format their components. This includes - `mermaid` [example](https://mermaid.js.org/config/usage.html#simple-full-example), where the mermaid diagrams are formatted in `&lt;pre/>` elements for post-processing by mermaid js. Having the plugin enabled causes the buttons to be inserted in the element which should only contain the diagram code, causing the mermaid diagrams to fail to render because of the added syntax inside the block.


### Steps to Reproduce
Add to your site.json
'''
  "plugins": [
    "codeBlockWrapButtons",
    "codeBlockCopyButtons"
  ]
'''

We can test a negative impact of this side effect, try adding some ASCII Art as so:

'''
&lt;pre>
   /\_/\
  ( o.o )
   > &hat; &lt;
&lt;/pre>
'''

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/5eb35017-2c10-4e56-b60e-69a92305eb21)

Both copy and wrap buttons will show up beside the cat. (They should not show up since the cat is not code, the buttons should only show up for code blocks)

### Others

https://github.com/MarkBind/markbind/blob/2cadb784fb53f6135ddd070056190142b50dc6d4/packages/core-web/src/styles/markbind.css#L288-L307


PRs #1043 and #1668 also add direct changes to `markbind.css`, which also have similar negative side effects (on mermaid, and possibly for future implementation). I propose to 1. shift the css changes into the plugins instead of adding it globally, and 2. better scope the css rules to minimize side effects:

This was also mentioned in the PR, I think it was a good catch which would have prevented this portion of the issue:

https://github.com/MarkBind/markbind/pull/1043#pullrequestreview-364223292

> Just a follow-up thought: It feels kinda odd that we add plugin styles to the main markbind.css file. Perhaps we should come up with a better way for plugin writers to keep assets contained within the plugin folder itself.

We can do this by using cheerio to add the style changes through head, or link it as an additional css file, instead of directly adding to the markbind css. This would be better for maintenance in the future as the css would be located together with the plugin.

Some overall refactoring would be good.

- [CommonMark spec for ''' (backticks fenced code blocks))](https://spec.commonmark.org/0.31.2/#fenced-code-blocks)

### Describe the bug and the steps to reproduce it

Test Sites have hydration Issues. 

This could be related to `&lt;span>` and invalid HTML rendered. And also special tags. Requires further investigation.

> A `&lt;div>` is a block-level element, whereas a &lt;span> is an inline element. When wrapping block-level elements (such as `&lt;p>, &lt;table>, &lt;div>`, etc.) inside a `&lt;span>`, it results in invalid HTML. This can cause hydration issues in frameworks like Vue, React, and Svelte because:
> * DOM Mismatch: The server might render valid block-level elements, but the browser may restructure them due to invalid nesting. This leads to hydration errors because the expected DOM tree differs from the actual one.
> * Unexpected CSS Behavior: Block-level elements inside an inline &lt;span> may not inherit expected styles, leading to layout inconsistencies.
> * Breaking Semantic HTML: Wrapping blocks in &lt;span> violates HTML rules, which could lead to accessibility and SEO issues.

`test_site`

### Please confirm that you have searched existing issues in the repo

### Tell us about your environment

Win 11

### MarkBind version

5.6.0

### Describe the bug and the steps to reproduce it

The v-closeable directive currently attaches mouseover and mouseout event listeners directly to the DOM element without any cleanup logic. This leads to memory leaks and duplicate event listener bindings when the directive element is toggled with v-if or when the component is unmounted and remounted. (Edge case if the directive is used in other vue components).

https://github.com/MarkBind/markbind/blob/c8f0e1a817e5b4ceb00c38ed5727c84c548fbcc9/packages/vue-components/src/directives/Closeable.js#L1-L69

### Suggested Fix

* Store the event listener functions (e.g., in el._closeable) when adding them
* On unmounting, we remove the event listeners

```
el.removeEventListener('mouseover', el._closeable.onMouseOver);
el.removeEventListener('mouseout', el._closeable.onMouseOut);
delete el._closeable;
```


### Expected behavior

The directive should clean up event listeners on unmount to avoid memory leaks and ensure no duplicate bindings occur.

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 24 10:26:16]%%

### Please confirm that you have searched existing issues in the repo

Yes, I have searched the existing issues

### Any related issues?

_No response_

### Tell us about your environment

Win 11

### MarkBind version

5.6.0

### Describe the bug and the steps to reproduce it

To reproduce:

```
<div v-closeable>
  Plain text with closeable directive 
</div>

vs.

<div v-closeable>

  Markdown with closeable directive 
</div>
```

Here is a screenshot:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/59659422-b661-466f-a436-a61cd4e9b507)

See that the `v-closeable` directive does not work with plain text.

If not familiar, some relevant understanding of 'plain text', 'markdown text', and 'closeable'.

**Markdown Text vs Plaintext**
* https://markbind.org/userGuide/usingHtmlJavaScriptCss.html#markdown-in-html
* https://markbind.org/userGuide/components/presentation.html#use-of-markdown-in-content

**Closeable Directive** (not obvious)
* https://markbind.org/userGuide/reusingContents.html#allowing-users-to-remove-some-contents

(Note that the built-in closeable directive in MarkBind shows a popup that allows it to be closed into a link.)

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/28ce08b3-d06b-45d4-9067-f6e3f6fd1bce)


### Expected behavior

Should work for plain text too. (shouldn't work only for elements such as markdown elements or `<p>` elements etc.

### Anything else?

This is due to this line:

https://github.com/MarkBind/markbind/blob/c8f0e1a817e5b4ceb00c38ed5727c84c548fbcc9/packages/vue-components/src/directives/Closeable.js#L52-L57

Line 54: `el.children`.

This is an issue if the element contains text nodes (e.g., from whitespace, line breaks, or raw text content), those won't be selected by `el.children`. But if you're trying to move all contents, including those text nodes for plain text (e.g., `Plain text`), text nodes are lost  so the `<div>` will appears empty.

Instead, we should use `el.childNode`. `Array.from(el.childNodes).forEach(child => content.append(child));`

Lifted from: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Node/childNodes
> It is important to keep in mind that childNodes includes all child nodes, including non-element nodes like text and comment. To get a collection containing only elements, use [Element.children](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/children) instead.
</panel>
