### Describe the bug and the steps to reproduce it

Due to a difference in `portal-vue` rendering mechanism from vue 2 to vue 3, the styling applied to site-nav, page-nav, overlaysource etc. and components that may use `portal-vue` may have become overly complicated and less sensible. 

Let's take the chance to refactor the styling logic. 

Additionally, anyone who might want to take on this issue could possibly also do some investigation into using Vue 3's Teleport feature, since it is related. I think that handling this issue would be a good way to start to understand how `portal-vue`, and `Teleport` work.

> Vue 3 has a new Teleport feature which replaces the portal-vue plugin in vue 2.
> Vue 3 is the current, latest major version of Vue. It contains new features that are not present in Vue 2, such as Teleport, Suspense, and multiple root elements per template

https://vuejs.org/guide/built-ins/teleport 

This means that MarkBind could possibly do away with having `portal-vue` as a dependency in the vue components that use it. This could make the code base much easier to understand as it would be more unified.


The investigation of using Teleport can cumulate into a separate issue, handled by a separate PR.

----

I have investigated and identified the cause of regression for site-nav and page-nav whitespace. 

This was due to a change in `portal-vue` rendering mechanism, specifically [portal-target no longer rendering a root element](https://portal-vue.linusb.org/guide/migration.html#portaltarget-component)
* A high-level explanation - Due to this expectation, the style attribute accounting for the `--sticky-header-height` was applied twice, causing this whitespace.
* Fix: applied a parent div to `portal-target` to 'absorb' this styling to maintain the expectation as per `vue-portal` v2. I have also done a rough check for other components that use portal-vue if such fix is required, but not needed as their styling is not affected as per a preliminary check.

* We can consider refactoring this in the future.  However, note that the change to refactor is not too trivial and requires some significant understanding of current styling in `main.css`, with regards to `#page-nav` and `#site-nav`, and how it interacts with `Overlay`, `OverlaySource`, and `portal-vue`.

_Originally posted by @gerteck in https://github.com/MarkBind/markbind/issues/2622#issuecomment-2744983002_
            

### Expected behavior

Simplify Styling Logic

Possibly use `Teleport` instead of `portal-vue` (handle in separate PR?)

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 09 19:32:17]%%

I am proposing to up the priority of this issue. (To at least p.Medium, if not high).

Some context to why the simple act of ignoring render files can drastically improve overhead and developer experience.

## Context and Explanation to understand this Issue

What is the `page-vue.render,js` function? This function is pre-generated on the server side, and sent over to the web client to render / hydrate the HTML received. Currently, in the Vue 2 implementation of MarkBind, this is where this function is generated: https://github.com/MarkBind/markbind/blob/8c9de42d78a67e4e73d8ed06c39d741ed71ddeb2/packages/core/src/Page/PageVueServerRenderer.ts#L39-L68

For more information, read up to MarkBind's [Server Side Rendering](https://markbind.org/devdocs/devGuide/design/serverSideRendering.html). (I think that it can be more descriptive - which is another issue for a subsequent time). So, whenever there is a change in the html content, there will inevitably be a change in the js render function. Note that these render functions can be more than thousands of lines long, with numerous characters per line. Because these render functions are auto-compiled, they are not meant to be human readable.


Currently for the snapshot tests, the render function files are not ignored. An example of the render function file is:

https://github.com/MarkBind/markbind/blob/8c9de42d78a67e4e73d8ed06c39d741ed71ddeb2/packages/cli/test/functional/test_site/expected/index.page-vue-render.js#L1-L337

The snapshot tests currently check for differences in rendered HTML, AND the page render function - which is unnecessary and adds considerable overhead. For example, I make a change that causes a regression in the rendered HTML file. We see that the test detects at least two differences - one in the `index.html`, and one in the `render function`

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/98b9e836-1c45-439a-a4e8-35ebef157fd8)

The change in index.html shown is useful. The change in the render function is not as much so. Additionally, because the render function is sometimes generated in a single line, unrelated changes pollute the CLI and makes it hard to identify the change or regression.

Furthermore, this effectively doubles or exponentially increases the workload of the snapshot tests (render functions are understandably more verbose than finished, rendered HTML), making it take at least double as much time to check diffs.

### Fix 

Gitignore the page-vue.render.js files containing the vue applications as the diffs are unreadable.

</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 29 14:06:53]%%

I wanted to raise an issue about this but realized it was a known issue. I wanted to add some context and understanding, and summarize the discussion, for future developers who might work on this issue:

**Issue**: Some Vue components are using scoped styles. (e.g. `submenu`) Some vue components are not using scoped styles. (e.g. `pic`). Currently, there is no clear direction to use or not. So the usage of scoped in vue components styling is inconsistent now.

**Benefit of using `scoped`**:
* If not scoped, class names and css used can `leak` globally, and can affect user specified elements and classes in the rare case they use the same class name. 

Here, I use the example of styles defined in `Pic.vue`, and show how the non-scoped style could theoretically be an issue.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/2ac311df-910f-41d7-91ee-9b636a0fcea9)

Hence, if it is scoped, there will not be any unwanted global css effects. (Second row)

**Disadvantage of using `scoped`**:
* Performance hit of `scoped`. [vue](https://vuejs.org/api/sfc-css-features.html#scoped-style-tips), [vue-loader](https://vue-loader.vuejs.org/guide/scoped-css.html#dynamically-generated-content)
* Styling becomes more intentional and deliberate, making it harder. This is because to affect child components (E.g. slotted content, other components) selectors such as `deep` need to be used. [deep](https://vuejs.org/api/sfc-css-features.html#deep-selectors)


Moving forward:
* Consider impact on performance and decide accordingly.
* If choosing to not scope, rather the focus should be on standardization across components, and standardizing namespacing of styles used, and perhaps adding this in the documentation to be known to users.

> So any attempt at this should be motivated by standardisation (also taking the opportunity to namespace our styles)
</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Feb 05 14:19:02]%%

## Vue Migration Vue 2 to Vue 3

Vue Migration Guide [here](https://v3-migration.vuejs.org/)

Issues that typically come up are related to both breaking Vue framework API changes and dependencies used in Vue 2 vs Vue 3.

### **Compilation and SSR of Vue (Core):**

- [ ] `Page/PageVueServerRenderer.ts` needs to be updated
1. 'vue-template-compiler' has been replaced by '@vue/compiler-sfc', hence`compileVuePageAndCreateScript` method which compiles page into Vue Application to get the render function must be updated.

2. `renderVuePage`: Method that Renders Vue page app into html string (Vue SSR). Ensure that it works during migration process. 

### **Webpack bundling (Core-Web)**
- [ ] `core-web` library needs to be updated
1. Update `core-web/src/index.js` setup process. Ensure setup functions for mounting Vue apps are not affected.

Issue I currently face here:
- pageVueServerRenderer attaches the render function
- core-web source uses the render function
for Vue 3, the way the render function is created and consumed is different. I noticed that @\EltonGohJH 's old PR didnt manage to resolve this and hence disabled SSR - trying to resolve this.

 Relevant Changelog: 
> Global Mounting: Vue.js 2: The global Vue instance is used to mount the root component. Vue.js 3: Introduces createApp for creating the application instance and makes the mounting process more explicit.

| Feature              | Vue 2                          | Vue 3                          |
|----------------------|--------------------------------|--------------------------------|
| Instance Creation    | `new Vue()`                    | `createApp()`                  |
| Global Configuration | On Vue constructor             | On app instance                |
| Global APIs          | Attached to Vue                 | Instance methods on app        |
| Reactivity System    | `Object.defineProperty`        | `Proxy`                        |
| Composition API      | Not available                  | Available                      |
| Fragments            | Single root element required   | Multiple root elements allowed |
| Teleport             | Not available                  | Built-in `&lt;teleport>` support  |

* In Vue 2, plugins add global level functionality. In Vue 3, each `createApp` call creates completely isolated app instance with its own config and global properties. Due to differences, the Vue instance is setup differently.
* Migrating from `new Vue` to createSSRApp(): case study [here](https://v3.ru.vuejs.org/guide/render-function.html) on using render function
* In Vue2, static render functions explicitly separated from main render function, but in Vue3, it is not. Hence, only one render function. (`compileVuePageAndCreateScript`)
* package `vue-server-renderer` is for Vue 2.0. Corresponding functionality for Vue 3 is in `@vue/server-renderer`, which is actually a dependency of the main `vue` package.


2. `VueCommonAppFactory.js`.The appFactory helps create the Vue app instances needed for each page, to set up the necessary configurations. Configure it if necessary for Vue 3, and dependencies used if any.

### **Vue Components SFCs**
- [ ] Vue-Components Library needs to be updated

- Update vue-components library where needed.
Note: Vue 2 Options API -&gt; Vue 3 Options API should not have too many changes. Should be the most straightforward process. However, a lot of dependencies have to be updated such as `floating vue`, etc. Not too sure yet. Working on vue rendering first.

### **Plugins:**
- [ ] Update necessary plugins 
1. Ensure usability and non-regression of `dataTable` and `Mermaid` plugins as they use Vue Directives.

 Relevant Changelog: 
>  Custom Directives: Vue.js 2: Custom directives are registered globally using Vue.directive. Vue.js 3: Custom directives are registered using the app.directive method, making it more modular and scoped to the app instance.


### **Others:**
- Why Migrate to Vue 3?
Vue2 has reached EOL, (end-2023) and will not receive any type of support. Packages supporting Vue2 used may not be maintained by extension. Vue3 has TypeScript support, noticeable performance improvements and more responsive application. Also has smaller bundle size. However, Vue 3 does not support IE13 (internet explorer). Migration is a time intensive process with codebase understanding required.


- What about considering letting vue2 and vue3 co-exist? 
We can use a migration build (Vue 2.7) that allows both Vue 2 & 3 code in a single codebase. Once done, migrate over to Vue 3.  However, I faced some issues with getting `@vue/compat` to work.

### **Sources:** 
- [Migration QA](https://www.monterail.com/blog/vue-3-migration-qa)
- [Vue2-Vue3 Differences](https://blog.shiftasia.com/difference-between-vuejs-2-and-3-when-to-use-them/)
- [Official Migration Guide](https://v3-migration.vuejs.org/migration-build.html)

Issues faced:
- No documentation in most packages, most just specify 'For detailed API references and options, check out the source type definitions in GitHub Repo'   

Will open a draft PR soon regarding work done on this. 
</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Feb 26 00:33:06]%%

Duplicated comment from #2597 as more relevant to this issue.

Some contextual knowledge for anyone reading this to better understand from quick glance: very simply, 

> The DataTable and Mermaid plugins work by manipulating the page after its been rendered by Vue.

> For the DataTable plugin, it first looks for custom &lt;d-table> elements, then converts them into regular HTML tables. Based on their attributes, like sortable or searchable, it applies the necessary configuration to make them interactive using the jQuery DataTable plugin.

> The Mermaid plugin operates similarly, searching for Mermaid-specific elements on the page after its loaded. It then uses Mermaid's rendering functions (using loaded js script) to convert those elements into diagrams.

---

I think we could consider different implementations to make this work

## Alternative Implementations
### Mount Multiple Vue instance for each Mermaid Element
This is alternative to attaching the directive to parent app Vue instance.  Initializing a new vue instance for each Mermaid diagram, registering the mermaid directive for that specific instance.
Ensures that each diagram has its own scoped configuration and avoids issues with Vue 3's global app instance limitations. However, this could lead to performance overhead if many Mermaid diagrams are rendered on a page.

### Direct Mutation of Mermaid Elements
Directly mutate Mermaid elements outside of Vues reactive. Could involve simply manipulating the DOM and invoking Mermaids rendering functions manually on element. Since the script runs after html is hydrated by Vue on client side. 

## Plugin vs. Default Features

Making it a plugin vs. default feature: I think if we make it default there are definitely size and performance impacts, thank you for pointing it out, overlooked this crucial aspect.

Considering this, I think it definitely makes sense to keep these features as plugins.

### Difference in size / performance

A quick test on [markbind.org](https://markbind.org/) shows 
(`dev tools` -&gt; `sources` -&gt; `plugins/dataTable/datatables.min.js` || `mermaid-5a5980d4.js`)
* mermaid.js file to be at 322kb, 
* datatable.js + css file at 192kb
 
which is actually quite hefty. E.g. if you load markbind.org, you need to load (~0.5 mb) of just the plugin `js` scripts. In fact, right now, even if you don't have any datatable or mermaid on the current page you need to load these script, as long as you enabled the plugins&lt;sup>1&lt;/sup>. 

If we continue this approach, providing mermaid offline support just mean to bundle it as needed as done with DataTable.


One quick way I can think of is that perhaps we can provide a toggle through plugin context to toggle between offline support and online support - what do you think?


## Side Note

&lt;sup>1&lt;/sup> I just realized there is potential for easy quick efficiency fix to current mermaid plugin - if no mermaid elements then we don't load mermaid script, because now it indiscriminately loads mermaid script on every page on load, if plugin is enabled @Tim-Siu . I can make a quick PR (#2614) to demonstrate what I mean. 


</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Apr 29 10:11:18]%%

Hi @GrassHeadd, thank you for raising the issue! 

The closing button is the feature of the custom vue directive that enables users to close / minimize elements for better viewability while navigating pages. It is an overlay positioned absolutely at the top left of the element, it currently overlaps the content slightly. 
* Note that this would make it hard to cause an expected behavior of shifting the content within the element, since it is an overlay.

https://github.com/MarkBind/markbind/blob/9c33eb47c4c4e79f1a97b1acc4173aa53fcff195/packages/vue-components/src/directives/Closeable.js#L1-L69


Given that the close button only appears when the cursor is hovering over the element, and that it is designed to be small and unobtrusive, I believe it generally does not interfere significantly with content readability. However, in cases like the activity diagram where the content is dense and important, I suppose it could be improved.

We could consider adding some repositioning options for the button (e.g., top-right) or adding padding/margin to shift the content slightly to avoid being covered when hovered etc. Depending on discussion and further input with the team, we could look into this issue, or close the issue if it is deemed less of a priority.


Thanks again for the feedback and contribution!  I also recommend you look into our list of issues if you would like to contribute! 

</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Apr 12 09:44:51]%%

> As for using "@" to indicate color, I am thinking would it be possible to just use "#" will a more robust parsing mechanism?

Users can specify a color using hex, for e.g. `#000000`. Using `#` to indicate color may lead to colors that are specified using hex to be incorrectly parsed. For e.g `1[:]##000000` will result in the color being wrongly parsed.
</panel>

<panel type="primary" popup-url="https://github.com/MarkBind/markbind/pull/2649#issuecomment-2799550063" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**18 :octicon-code-review:** (commented on own PR #2649)
</div>

%%[created at: 2025 Apr 13 10:15:31]%%

> > > As for using "@" to indicate color, I am thinking would it be possible to just use "#" will a more robust parsing mechanism?
> > 
> > 
> > Users can specify a color using hex, for e.g. `#000000`. Using `#` to indicate color may lead to colors that are specified using hex to be incorrectly parsed. For e.g `1[:]##000000` will result in the color being wrongly parsed.
> 
> I think there was a typo. What I meant was something like `1[:]#00ff00` or `1[:]#y`. I think in general putting both hex color codes and color names after the same `#` will not lead to confusion? Correct me if I am wrong. I just thought it would be good to avoid introducing new symbols as far as possible to make it easier on the users.

Currently what the code does is it will split by `@` to obtain the color specified on the right of `@`, the color will then be added to the HTML like this `style="background-color:$``{``color``}``;"`.

If split by `#` to obtain the resulting hex, say `000000`, there will need to be additional checks before adding it into the HTML. This is because the current approach will result in something like `style="background-color:000000;"`

What about something that is not already present?
</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Feb 06 22:41:58]%%

### Please confirm that you have searched existing issues in the repo

Yes, I have searched the existing issues

### Any related issues?

#2051

### What is the area that this feature belongs to?

Reader Usability

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.

I noticed that when I highlight text within a fenced block, the highlight color is black or grey depending on whether we are in light or dark mode. It can be frustrating because the highlight doesn't stand out very well.

For example in light mode, I think the highlight in orange stands out better as compared to the default highlight color

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/1797d5d7-da04-48c9-8a37-a6fd105c0324)

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/fc6fd2f3-b733-453d-a9e1-deb5997459f6)

### Describe the solution you'd like

I would like to propose allowing users to specify an additional field when typing out inline code. In the example below, the color field newly added.

```

java'''``{``.line-numbers highlight-lines="2" color="Orange"``}``
public class RandomNumberGenerator ``{``
    private int min;
    private int max;

    public RandomNumberGenerator(int min, int max) ``{``
        this.min = min;
        this.max = max;
    ``}``

    public int generate() ``{``
        return min + (int) (Math.random() * (max - min + 1));
    ``}``

    public static void main(String[] args) ``{``
        RandomNumberGenerator rng = new RandomNumberGenerator(1, 100);
        System.out.println("Random Number: " + rng.generate());
    ``}``
``}``
'''
```

### Describe alternatives you've considered

N.A.

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 31 11:57:46]%%

### Please confirm that you have searched existing issues in the repo

Yes, I have searched the existing issues

### Any related issues?

_No response_

### What is the area that this feature belongs to?

_No response_

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.

The highlights in the fenced code has a very squarish highlight. This is in contrast to normal highlight, where there are paddings and rounded corners on both ends. I think it would be better if we have consistencies between the 2.

The first image here shows a highlight in the fenced code.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/b712e1be-6eac-495b-8889-e3cdd496a67c)

The second image here shows a highlight outside of the fenced code.
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/07db6dd9-ec54-410e-80c7-f44bf7238c86)

### Describe the solution you'd like

I have actually tried tackling this problem for a week or so. My initial plan is to simply add a padding and rounded border when generating the html files. There are the 2 files reponsible for the creation of html files.
1. [https://github.com/MarkBind/markbind/blob/master/packages/core/src/lib/markdown-it/highlight/Highlighter.ts](https://github.com/MarkBind/markbind/blob/master/packages/core/src/lib/markdown-it/highlight/Highlighter.ts)
Adding the appropriate paddings and rounded borders for the whole text and whole line highlight will work fine in this file. However, the problem lies with highlighting partial texts

2. [https://github.com/MarkBind/markbind/blob/master/packages/core/src/html/codeblockProcessor.ts](https://github.com/MarkBind/markbind/blob/master/packages/core/src/html/codeblockProcessor.ts)
If we were to simply add the padding and rounded borders while generating the html files, the highlight will appear disjoint as shown in the picture below. This is due to the recursive nature of the code, as it applies the highlight to each section 1 by 1.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d0516392-769f-4aab-92d0-9d7ac8a44d7f)

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.

This is an enhancement of PR #2649 and is suggested by @tlylt . To highlight in a fenced code block, we can now either specify a color or a hex value. It would be good to support [bootstrap classes](https://getbootstrap.com/docs/5.3/customize/color/) as well!

### Describe the solution you'd like

There would probably be a need to discern if the color specified is a bootstrap class (--bs-emphasis-color) or a hex/color (#000000/black), before they could be further processed.

After which, just create the HTML as needed, which is pretty straight-forward.

> In my opinion it's a known risk that styles might break if users choose to update the default css, any other styling might also break if done incorrectly. Not that there's no need to improve the feature itself, but the approach this PR is going for doesn't resolve the problem nicely without introducing "new problems":
> 
> * `list-style-position: inside;` styling wise I would prefer to keep it outside, so there's no "misaligned" issue

I agree that keeping styling outside should be preferred as it keeps the alignment of the list elements. Perhaps we can add it as a known issue/ warning to users who are trying to insert custom css stylesheets into their documents?

I also came across this [thread ](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/10428720/how-to-keep-indent-for-second-line-in-ordered-lists-via-css)on stack overflow where the accepted answer suggested using the browser's table layout algorithm to achieve the same effect. I've tried it out and it does preserve the outside property and keeps the indentation while avoiding the hidden list numbers.

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/9e8c8ac7-074b-417d-a32a-e1be8544c80a)

I have not found any regressions yet. Have yet to test it out on macOS. @tlylt what do you thhink? I have pushed the commit if you want to try it out.
</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Jan 29 17:30:42]%%

> > Would it be better if this was left as a tip instead? Though allowed, according to proper heuristics, if there are multiple correct answers, users should choose to use a checkbox question instead of a multiple choice question.
> 
> I don't think this is true for all cases - I would consider an MCQ question with multiple correct answers vs. a Checkbox question with multiple correct answers to be two different use cases. (The first case might be useful if a question setter wants to be more "lenient" in a textbook quiz)
> 
> Leaving it as a tip is likely not going to cause huge problems per se, but given that (1) this issue was raised since the tip was initially thought to refer to the example above the tip, and (2) we can have more examples as needed (we are doing it for the [Fill-in-the-Blanks Questions section](https://markbind.org/userGuide/components/others.html#fill-in-the-blanks-questions)), it might be worthwhile to at least clear up the potential confusion.
> 
> If providing an example seems to be overkill, we can expand / reword the tip so that there is no ambiguity, i.e. make it clear that the example shown is meant to be a single-answer question.

Thanks for sharing your perspective. I see your point about MCQ and Checkbox questions serving different purposes, especially in cases where flexibility in grading is desired. 

Given that the original concern stemmed from potential ambiguity in the tip, I agree that we should ensure clarity and should go along with adding an example to avoid ambiguity while still showing that it is possible to do so.
</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Apr 06 02:57:30]%%

After spending some time investigating the issue, I noted that the most likely cause of the issue was due to the `overflow:hidden` property in `main.css`. However, a larger issue lies in `ol` and `ul`.

Inspecting the 2103 website on safari and chrome on macOS and adding custom list elements, I get this result:

<img width="2560" alt="Image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/0433b1ca-1452-427c-a524-9f9971acaecf" />

- Tested with list of 9 elements and 10 elements
- In the safari browser, the tenth place is totally hidden by the `overflow:hidden` property 
- In the chrome browser, the 1 of the tenth place is actually partially hidden away as it slightly flows out of the content area and gets hidden


Implications:
- Removing `overflow:hidden` is likely not going to be a long term solution as it might be needed for some use cases.
- Having > 100 elements in the list (though uncommon) will hide away the hundredth place in both safari and chrome browsers as shown below (going from 99th element to 100th element in chrome browser on macOS): 
<img width="530" alt="Image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/a1bf8a92-f156-43a3-a267-3da4f19e9961" />

Looking into `markbind.css` and `bootstrap.css`:
- `padding-left: 1.5rem` sets a padding of 24px but for tenth place to properly shows, it needs at least 32px.
- By default, `ol` and `ul` uses `list-style-position: outside` which right-aligns the list numbers
- `bootstrap.css` also specifies a 32px `padding-left` to `ol` and `ul` and so lists that are >100 do not display their hundredth place 

Potential solutions: 
1. Change to `list-style-position: inside` which will left-align the list numbers while preserving `padding-left: 1.5rem`. This displays the numbers starting from the largest position as shown below. However, the drawback would be that the start of text would gradually be off skewed as the list number increases as noted by the start of the 10th postion.
<img width="435" alt="Image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/ba95b64c-28ee-46ab-a46c-73a1c7e72548" />

Things to note: 
- Solution should keep indentation reasonable, especially for mobile devices (#1669)
</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Feb 01 01:40:30]%%

Due to how the `pull_request_target` trigger runs in the context of the base of the pull request, rather than in the context of the merge commit, getting the failing check (`.github/workflows/pending.yml`) to pass is not possible within PRs (to my knowledge). 

This problem is only possible because previously passing checks auto-fail after 2025-01-30 due to the [deprecation](https://github.blog/changelog/2024-04-16-deprecation-notice-v3-of-the-artifact-actions/). Can we make an exception to merge this in? 

Future runs of the workflow should pass after merging this in as the base of the PRs for those runs would have the updated `pending.yml` workflow.

References:
* https://docs.github.com/en/actions/writing-workflows/choosing-when-your-workflow-runs/events-that-trigger-workflows#pull_request_target
* https://runs-on.com/github-actions/pull-request-vs-pull-request-target/

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 20 14:07:38]%%

As discussed on Monday, custom repository time periods will only be supported in portfolio view mode, due to its intended use case.

Here will be the intended behavior:

**Default view:** Disallow / ignore custom repository time periods (#2334). Frontend follows existing behavior as custom repository time periods are not supported in this view.

**Portfolio view:** Displayed summary charts to be unaffected by filter dates, solely relying on the date ranges in `summary.json`. No longer need to consider interaction with filter dates. Trim timeline will still be allowed.

I'll make these FE changes in #2320 and close this PR as the changes are interdependent.

---

For future reference, in case supporting custom repository time periods in default view becomes needed (non-exhaustive):

1. Decide how custom repository time periods should interact with the filter dates. 
a. Intersection of the 2 date ranges likely requires changes to adjust selectable filter dates to make sure all custom repository date ranges are included.
b. Ignore filter dates and only display the custom repository date range if provided. Backend needs to add a field to indicate if custom repository date range was provided.
c. Union and filter date range priority does not seem to make sense as commits may seem missing.
2. Consider what should be displayed when grouped by author
</panel>

...

### Tell us about your environment

* **OS and Version:** MacOS
* **Web Browser and Version (if applicable):** Firefox

### Please include the steps to reproduce the bug.

1. On a ramp, select a tight range around a commit. The zoom view sometimes do not include the commit.

<div slot="header">

**58 :octicon-issue-opened:** (created issue #2422: Support shared Cypress test suites)
</div>

%%[created at: 2025 Apr 17 12:31:36]%%

&lt;!--
  Before opening a new issue, please search existing issues:  https://github.com/reposense/RepoSense/issues
-->

### What feature(s) would you like to see in RepoSense
&lt;!--
  Provide a clear and concise description of the feature.
-->

With the recent addition of the `portfolio` mode of the report, we now have 2 different modes of the report. The previously existing Cypress tests only run on the `default` mode. There is an entirely different set of Cypress tests for the `portfolio` mode.

This is not ideal as we expect some of the existing functionalities to work the same way on both modes, but is currently not being tested for the `portfolio` mode.

### Is the feature request related to a problem?

&lt;!--
  Provide a clear and concise description of what the problem is.
  Ex. I have an issue when [...]
-->


### If possible, describe the solution

&lt;!--
  Here would be a good place to talk about the solution or the
  approach that can be taken.
-->

I propose refactoring the Cypress tests into:
* `cypress/tests/common`: Majority of the older tests should for under here and ran on both report modes. 
* `cypress/tests/default`: For `default` exclusive behavior.
* `cypress/tests/portfolio`: For `portfolio` exclusive behavior.

This would make tests easier to maintain while ensuring better test coverage of the `portfolio` mode.

### If applicable, describe alternatives you've considered

&lt;!--
  Let us know about other solutions you've tried or researched.
-->

  You might want to link related issues here if you haven't already.
-->

%%[created at: 2025 Apr 25 14:50:31]%%

&lt;!--
  Before opening a new issue, please search existing issues:  https://github.com/reposense/RepoSense/issues
-->

### What feature(s) would you like to see in RepoSense
&lt;!--
  Provide a clear and concise description of the feature.
-->

Now that custom sort order (follows initial order of rows in `repo-config.csv`) has been added in #2331, it would be better for portfolio mode to use that ordering instead of the current sort by ascending group name.

Reasoning is that there is currently no way for the user (portfolio creator) to specify the order of the repositories in portfolio mode. It would be better for the user to be able to customize the order through the config file, so they can put more important / recent projects at the top.

### Is the feature request related to a problem?

&lt;!--
  Provide a clear and concise description of what the problem is.
  Ex. I have an issue when [...]
-->


### If possible, describe the solution

&lt;!--
  Here would be a good place to talk about the solution or the
  approach that can be taken.
-->

For portfolio mode, change the filter settings when filtering repositories to use the custom sort order. 

It should be a small change in `c-summary-portfolio.vue` (as well as tests).

<panel type="info" popup-url="https://github.com/reposense/RepoSense/issues/2334#issuecomment-2758629567" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**63 :octicon-comment:** (commented on issue #2334)
</div>

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 28 00:18:19]%%

The reason we decided to revert the custom date range for default view was that the main intended use case that was discussed for them was the portfolio view, while supporting it for default view caused a lot of weird cases that needed to be handled on the FE.

I think if we disallow illegal date range that falls outside on the BE, the FE complications that we had previously should be manageable. 

We just need to decide on how should the filter since and until dates in the form interact with the custom date range and merge and consider if any of the side effect may seem misleading or too complicated:

1. Intersection: Possible. We will display warning if they do not intersect. With merging groups, it seems misleading to me as it might seem like there are missing commits from the ramp when it is actually because of those commits being out of range for that repository, with no indication of it. Could be a non-issue if the user strictly only cares about the specified date range.
2. Specified custom data ranges ignores filter: Complicated and unintuitive. Particularly with merging groups, we can get strange date indicators outside what is input in the filter dates in the form.
3. Union: Again strange date indicators outside what is input in the filter dates in form.
4. Filter dates in form takes priority: Also seems misleading to me due to seemingly missing commits, this time even outside merging groups. But again, depends on how you see it.

Overall, I think FE shouldn't have much issues implementing if we can decide on the intended behavior for above. I suggest adding support for custom date range in default view to be implemented as a separate issue as this simplified behavior would fulfil its intended use case for portfolio view while keeping default view unaffected.
</panel>

<panel type="info" popup-url="https://github.com/reposense/RepoSense/issues/2334#issuecomment-2758794289" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**64 :octicon-comment:** (commented on issue #2334)
</div>

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 28 01:02:11]%%

Yep I understand what Si Kai is suggesting and I agree that filter range taking priority (as current behavior) makes the most sense coming from the POV that report generators want to exclude certain commits and viewers should not care about any outside the range. 

Just for consideration, the case that I thought might be misleading to viewers was tracking something like IP (Week 1-6) and TP (Week 7-13). If a student makes a commit to IP after week 6, maybe due to extension, that commit might seem missing to the viewer (student) without knowledge of the configuration. There are ofc simple workarounds to mitigate this like having buffers etc, but just wanted to point out how it may be misleading in rare cases.

Also, if we're going with the filter range priority for default view, can I confirm that in portfolio mode, it should be handled differently and the date indicators displayed are the individual repository date ranges (as how it is implemented in #2340)?
</panel>

</panel>

<panel type="success" popup-url="https://github.com/reposense/RepoSense/pull/2338#issuecomment-2766757732" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**82 :octicon-code-review:** (review on PR #2338)
</div>

%%[created at: 2025 Apr 01 00:26:31]%%

I agree that the main factors affecting the time is the cloning and generating JSON. The time for parsing of CSV file may not be so significant compared to these two. The current implementation has done well in avoiding unnecessary re-execution of these two jobs and reducing the time for rerunning the program after small changes. Hence, a change to avoid parsing may not be as important as the current implementation.

However, a change should not be that complicated. I try to insert below code before running of `getRepoConfigurations` and it runs OK. Basically, just parse the blurb and write the JSON file and zip file before even parsing the CSV config. This is because the generated `configs` and `reportConfig` of parsing CSV or stand-alone config is actually not being used when re-updating the JSON file and zip files.

```
            blurbMap = cliArguments.getBlurbMap();

            if (cliArguments.isOnlyTextRefreshed()) ``{``
                Path summaryJsonPath = Paths.get(cliArguments.getOutputFilePath().toAbsolutePath().toString()
                        + "/" + SummaryJson.SUMMARY_JSON_FILE_NAME);
                if (!Files.exists(summaryJsonPath)) ``{``
                    throw new IOException("summary.json does not exist in the output folder. Aborting report generation.");
                ``}``
                SummaryJson updatedSummaryJson = SummaryJson.updateSummaryJson(summaryJsonPath, blurbMap,
                        formatter.format(ZonedDateTime.now(cliArguments.getZoneId())),
                        TimeUtil.getElapsedTime());

                FileUtil.writeJsonFile(updatedSummaryJson, cliArguments.getOutputFilePath().toAbsolutePath().toString()
                        + "/" + SummaryJson.SUMMARY_JSON_FILE_NAME);

                FileUtil.addOrReplaceFileInZipFile(
                        cliArguments.getOutputFilePath().toAbsolutePath(),
                        cliArguments.getOutputFilePath().toAbsolutePath(),
                        SummaryJson.SUMMARY_JSON_FILE_NAME,
                        FileUtil.ZIP_FILE);

                logger.info(TimeUtil.getElapsedTimeMessage());
                if (cliArguments.isAutomaticallyLaunching()) ``{``
                    ReportServer.startServer(SERVER_PORT_NUMBER, cliArguments.getOutputFilePath().toAbsolutePath());
                ``}``
                return;
            ``}``
``` 

This further reduced the time taken to generate report compared to my previous experiment (which is 0.72s). Not sure whether the benefit will be more significant if the size of CSV file increases.
<img width="890" alt="image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/efae2bcf-e21a-4736-b697-4c5a0c3e6536" />

If this is not so significant, we should leave it aside and just get the current implementation to be merged.

</panel>

There is a conflict between the date range filter and the dates specified in CSV (hardcoded dates). There may be a case which repos specified hardcoded time ranges that are non-overlapping and far away from one another.

<panel type="info" popup-url="https://github.com/reposense/RepoSense/issues/2334#issuecomment-2759936762" expanded>

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 28 09:25:40]%%

> > It is a bit hard to make sure the date range is consistent with the widely spread ranges. Therefore, we decide to restrict the hardcoded dates to portfolio mode. Under portfolio mode, the date range filter will be disable.
> 
> My thinking is, there is no need to make the two consistent with each other. We consider the two ways of specifying the range as _default-with-override_. That is, if hard-coded start/end is given for a repo, we use that for that repo (i.e., we consider it as an _override_). If there is no hard-coded start/end given, we use the since/until specified via CLI flags as start/end (i.e., we consider it as the _default_ to fall back on). So, it will same as we copy-pasted CLI since/until values to all repos that don't have hard-coded start/end. And, there will be no issue of 'illegal' date ranges.
> 
> However, I'm fine with not supporting both at the same time too -- it will be a very rare use case anyway. So, go with whichever the option that results in the simpler implementation.

That's the current behavior of the hard-coded start/end dates. If the user didn't specify the dates for either start or end in the CSV config, the backend will use the default since date or until date (either the ones specified by `--since` and `--until` flags or the one-month default period) for the respective repo configuration.
</panel>

<panel type="info" popup-url="https://github.com/reposense/RepoSense/issues/2334#issuecomment-2759948037" expanded>

**103 :octicon-comment:** (commented on issue #2334)
</div>

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 28 09:37:26]%%

In conclusion, there are several ways to redefine how the CSV config is using (correct me if I am wrong):
1. Limit the CSV date range to a subset of default date range (ones specified by flags or the default one month). Throw an error when the
2. Set overall earliest start date and latest end date for `summary.json`'s based on CSV config and default dates. Keep the current behavior on how each repo's date range is specified.

The BE should not have too much difficulty to handle both cases. If the FE is picking the correct info from the `summary.json`, the filter and the date range of each ramp should be consistent

So which approach should we choose? 
</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 29 15:41:13]%%

> Let's go with having the CSV file define the range of commits to fetch per repo. This way, we can avoid massive changes to frontend logic and allow our portfolio PR to proceed. So the behaviour will be as such per repo:
> 
> 1. CSV line present, CLI present: Range of commits will be taken from CSV line, and CSV line will be validated against CLI line.
> 2. CSV line present, CLI absent: Range of commits taken from CSV line. Overall range is the union of all ranges across CSV-specified repos.
> 3. CSV line absent (already implemented): Range of commits taken from CLI (if any, else default values for CLI)
> 
> Behaviour for the other views (e.g. Author, Chart, None) should remain the same since this is a backend change.
> 
> There are edge cases for partial information provided (e.g. start date/end date only): For CSV lines:
> 
> * If start date provided only, end date will be either 1: CLI end date if given, or 2: earliest date across all CSV-specified repos
> * If end date provided only, start date will be either 1: CLI start date if given, or 2: latest date across all CSV-specified repos
> 
> CLI defaults without any CSV dates specified remain the same. We will raise warnings for any behaviour that diverges from CLI defaults (e.g. when CSV dates are specified but CLI is not)
> 
> This means the following actions will be taken:
> 
> * [[#2334] Separate portfolio and normal mode#2340](https://github.com/reposense/RepoSense/pull/2340) not to be merged
> * [[#2305] FE: Support optimised portfolio view#2320](https://github.com/reposense/RepoSense/pull/2320) to be merged
> * New PR to validate CSV inputs and make inferences where relevant to be created.
> 
> Does anyone have any thoughts/objections/suggestions?
> 
> P.S.:
> 
> > Also, if we're going with the filter range priority for default view, can I confirm that in portfolio mode, it should be handled
> > differently and the date indicators displayed are the individual repository date ranges (as how it is implemented in [#2340](https://github.com/reposense/RepoSense/pull/2340))?
> 
> [@Airiinnn](https://github.com/Airiinnn), I forgot that portfolio mode removes the in-report date range filter, so there is actually a reason to diverge from default mode behaviour. My bad :P

I have some questions regarding the suggestions. For case 1 and case 2, how to handle the case where only one of the `--since` flag and `--until` flag is provided. Furthermore, do we need to consider the existence of `--period` flag?

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 31 23:48:53]%%

Another alternative implementation to handle the conflict between CLI and CSV dates is to set CSV dates has higher priority. The outer `sinceDate` and `untilDate` fields of `summary.json` (which should be the ones used for FE date range selector) will be the earliest start date and the latest end date of all repos. The CLI/default dates will be used if the CSV date is not provided.

Additional checks will be made for following cases cause potential conflicts:
1) CSV since date after CSV until date
2) CSV since date after CLI/default until date, CSV until date not provided
3) CSV until date before CLI/default since date, CSV since date not provided
4) CLI since date after CLI until date

This kindof gives users more choices as now they can choose to use CSV to restrict range of commits, or just want to use it to customize the result of certain repos?

@sopa301 @sikai00 Does this solution address the issue?

&lt;!--

### What feature(s) would you like to see in RepoSense
&lt;!--
  Provide a clear and concise description of the feature.
-->
When any PR or changes that have been made on main repo, we want to trigger a workflow that will test the whole report-generation logic at the `publish-Reposense` with the new changes. This is to detect early regression.

Work done in #2295 explores the use of `lighthouse CLI` to detect possible blank pages due to possible routing issues. 

To fully solve the issue, we may need to integrate the techniques to trigger workflow in another repository with Github Actions ([ref](https://medium.com/hostspaceng/triggering-workflows-in-another-repository-with-github-actions-4f581f8e0ceb)) 
 
### Is the feature request related to a problem?

&lt;!--
  Provide a clear and concise description of what the problem is.
  Ex. I have an issue when [...]
-->
#2285 
#2295 
### If possible, describe the solution

&lt;!--
  Here would be a good place to talk about the solution or the
  approach that can be taken.
-->

Some ideas on possible implementation:
1) The event will trigger a POST request to the relevant API that will trigger the workflow in `publish-Reposense`, the request's payload should contain information such as PR number or commit hash.
2) `publish-Reposense` need to check out to the correct version of main repo jar file using the payload through running the downloading utility scripts.
3) Set up `jekyll` building environment to run github pages on `publish-Reposense`'s github action runner
4) Deploy the website on github action runner
5) Use Lighthouse CLI to audit the website, it will exit with error when the page is blank.

-->
Useful resources:

- https://github.com/orgs/community/discussions/42316

%%[created at: 2025 Apr 08 13:52:14]%%

### If possible, describe the solution
In terms of the function code the only thing should be changing is the one in the `RepoConfigCsvParser.java`. Currently, the since date and until date are taken in the format of `dd/MM/yyyy` and then hardcoded into valid `LocalDatetime` object by manually adding the default since date start time and default until date end time.

A way to solve this issue is to relax the constraint on the format of date time input in the CSV. We can support both `dd/MM/yyyy` and `dd/MM/yyyyTHH:mm` at the same time. Only hardcoding and overwriting the dates is specific time is not provided.

It will be suitable for first-comer to work on this so that they can get a rough idea of how the arguments are parsed and the repos are analyzed from the experience of implementing this one.
</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Apr 14 22:56:32]%%

Thanks for pointing out this potential feature flaw!

The repos to condense is determine by the URL field `mergeGroup`. The param hash will associate a list of repo urls which should be included in the dashboard display. And after entering the search keyword, the param hash should remain constant other than the `search` field.

Based on my investigation if the user filter then merge the group, only the filtered repos will be condensed (in this case only repos with "W13-3" is actually merged). When user continue to filter another repo, the hash `mergeGroup` will not be updated. Hence, the new filtered file with keyword "W13-4" will not be condensed.

Here is the URL after searching for "W13-3"
```
https://nus-cs2103-ay2425s2.github.io/tp-dashboard/?search=W13-3&sort=groupTitle%20dsc&sortWithin=title&since=2025-02-21&timeframe=commit&mergegroup=AY2425S2-CS2103T-W13-3%2Ftp%5Bmaster%5D&groupSelect=groupByRepos&breakdown=false
```

Here is the URL after searching for "W13-4"
```
https://nus-cs2103-ay2425s2.github.io/tp-dashboard/?search=W13-4&sort=groupTitle%20dsc&sortWithin=title&since=2025-02-21&timeframe=commit&mergegroup=AY2425S2-CS2103T-W13-3%2Ftp%5Bmaster%5D&groupSelect=groupByRepos&breakdown=false
```

May be we can further discussion on how to improve the behavior of merging and filtering repos?
</panel>

> [@CYX22222003](https://github.com/CYX22222003) Ahh okay thanks for explaining how it works.

> Should the url change according to the filter settings be more intuitive in this case? Are there any upsides to keeping the param hash of the previous search result as compared to just applying it to every new search result? Since as a user, I would expect the selected settings to still be applied to my search results.

To clarify the previous search result is not kept, only the `mergeGroup` result is kept. And this field actually will be persistent even if you clear the search field. It seems that the current behavior of merging all groups just make an attempt to update the current filtered group and update the hash. 

I think the suggestion by @Incogdino indeed has a good point. A possible way is to keep the setting for merged setting in a Boolean variable and pass it around using URL hash. So every time can update the `merged groups` in `c-summary.vue` based on its existing values and the flag.

However, I am not sure whether this implementation will conflict with any current implementation or violate any assumptions and principles.

@sopa301 @jonasongg @joeng03 @Airiinnn Any idea about this issue?

Shared some suggestion for updating the UG. Also I reformat the proposed commit message because some of the lines are truncated with very few characters before the next word.

'''Support datetime (previously just date) for since and until in both
Backend and Frontend.

3 supported formats for since and until dates: 
1. DD/MM/YYYY
2. DD/MM/YYYY'T'HH:mm
3. DD/MM/YYYY'T'HH:mm:ss

For example:
`./gradlew run -Dargs="--since 31/12/2017T10:10"`


Rationale for using 'T' instead of blank space is to adhere to ISO
8601 format and prevent complicating the CLI input where it will need
an additional set of quotation marks to identify the space-separated
date.

Behavior: For since date, if hour/minute/seconds not supplied then
default to 0 for each. For until date, if hour/minute/seconds not 
supplied then default to 23, 59, 59 respectively. If only one date
(since or until) is provided, and a period is also provided (default
to 1 month in our existing project), the time of since is truncated
to 00:00:00 if until is supplied, and time of until is truncated to 
23:59:59 if since is supplied.


Note for systemtest: For "Asia/Singapore" timezone, on dates before
01-01-1982, where Singapore and Malaysia switched from UTC+07:30
to UTC+08:00, all date conversions will result in +7.5 hours instead
of +8 hours. For example, the Unix epoch 1970-01-01 00:00:00 will be 
1970-01-01 07:30:00 with "Asia/Singapore" timezone, but 
1970-01-01 08:00:00 with "UTC+08" timezone.
Reference: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UTC%2B07:30.
'''
</panel>

We will expect the blurb to be parse following the order in the `summary.json` (blurb 1 -&gt; blurb 2 -&gt; blurb 3)
But now repo blurb are parsing in order of (2 -&gt; 1 -&gt; 3) and chart in (3 -&gt; 2 -&gt; 1) which is unexpected. This does not actually affecting the project as the order of the blurb is parsed is not important, but it would be nice if the reason that affect the parsing order.

May refer to the `summary.json` files in the system test and look for the field of author blurb and chart blurb to see the orders.

%%[created at: 2025 Apr 03 15:50:57]%%

> Just a clarification about an edge case: when it is group by author, what is the sorting order of case like ``{``[1], [1], [1, 2], [1]``}`` ? This may be common in the case of CS2103T tp where more than one coder has the same order.


After looking into it, I realized that several other sorting options also face the same issue where there is no defined order if the values have a tie, for example, when grouped by repo, sort the groups by author displayName (there is a possible case where an author contributed to multiple repos, and is the lexicographically largest display name among contributors of both repos.

I would propose to resolve this ambiguity in another PR, where each grouping option (by author or repo) can only sort by a fixed set of fields (for example, sort by default order might not make sense for group by author, and sort by author displayName might not make sense for group by repo). Then for sort fields that might have the same value (for example, totalCommits might be the same for several authors/repos), maybe define a default way to break ties (for example, the default ordering of repos, or lexicogaphical order of author displayName.


</panel>

(!) Some chunks are larger than 500 kB after minification. Consider:

- Use build.rollupOptions.output.manualChunks to improve chunking: https://rollupjs.org/configuration-options/#output-manualchunks

<panel type="warning" popup-url="https://github.com/reposense/RepoSense/issues/2376" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**75 :octicon-issue-opened:** (created issue #2376: Resolve Ambiguity for ties in Sort by Groups)
</div>

%%[created at: 2025 Apr 03 15:52:47]%%

Related to #2331 

Several sorting options face the issue where there is no defined order if the sort values have a tie, for example, when grouped by repo, sort the groups by author displayName (there is a possible case where an author contributed to multiple repos, and is the lexicographically largest display name among contributors of both repos.

I would propose to resolve this ambiguity in a PR, where each grouping option (by author or repo) can only sort by a fixed set of fields (for example, sort by default order might not make sense for group by author, and sort by author displayName might not make sense for group by repo). Then for sort fields that might have the same value (for example, totalCommits might be the same for several authors/repos), maybe define a default way to break ties by unique fields (for example, the default ordering of repos, or lexicogaphical order of author GitId.
</panel>

<hr class="thick-1 border-secondary" />

<panel type="warning" popup-url="https://github.com/reposense/RepoSense/issues/2390" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**76 :octicon-issue-opened:** (created issue #2390: Support filtering commits by datetime)
</div>

%%[created at: 2025 Apr 07 17:19:18]%%

Refer to #2388 

We currently support filtering commits by date only.

Since we currently group the commits by dates, and each date has multiple commits, we can't do filtering based on datetime as of now. Propose to change the structure of authorDailyContributionsMap to support this. 

To minimize changes to the codebase, I suggest that we add an additional field for datetime to each commit grouped under the same date. When filtering, we only have to extend the existing filtering logic to filter the datetime for the first and last filtered date. 

For example, if "since" is `2020-01-01T00:02` and "until" is `2020-01-15T23:00`, then we only have to filter the dates as usual, then do additional filtering for commits grouped under `2020-01-01` for time >=00:02, and commits grouped under `2020-01-15` for time &lt;=23:00. 
</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Apr 01 00:01:09]%%

@CYX22222003 Thanks for the review! Yes, the re-parsing of the CSV files is expected. I kept this behavior for two main reasons:

1. Even when the configuration files are re-parsed, it doesn't introduce any side effects to later runs because the system skips the repo analysis and cloning steps in `reportGenerator.generateReposReport`. Only some information in the summary.json file gets updated, and these updates aren't affected by configuration changes.
2. I could have added code to skip parsing the configuration files, but it wouldn't make the system much faster. Using the same logic, I'd need to skip other parts too, and I don't think the performance benefit is worth the extra complexity.

Please let me know what you think. Thank you!
</panel>

<panel type="primary" popup-url="https://github.com/reposense/RepoSense/pull/2338#issuecomment-2767037515" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**7 :octicon-code-review:** (commented on own PR #2338)
</div>

%%[created at: 2025 Apr 01 02:17:15]%%

In my opinion, I don't think the performance improvement will be very significant for us to implement this explicitly. For the use case of large CSV files, I tried parsing around 1500 lines in the CSV file and I don't feel a significant performance decrease. It was around one second slower.

I also did a brief trial of skipping the re-parsing. It turns out that there are more complexities in the parsing so it cannot be skipped with just an if statement in the current code. It might involve altering some default behaviour so I think the current implementation will suffice considering the scale of this feature.

Feel free to let me know if you have any concerns!
</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 21 00:51:46]%%

This check is for the case when `reportConfig` is null due to `report-config.yaml` being invalid or empty This is different from the check in the `ReportConfiguration` constructor, which only happens when the YAML file parses correctly but is missing the `title` field.

Previously in `ArgsParser.java`, an invalid or empty `report-config.yaml` would create an empty `reportConfig` object (not null). I changed this behaviour so that `reportConfig` becomes null when the YAML file can't be parsed successfully hence `getTitle()` would not work in this case.

<panel type="warning" popup-url="https://github.com/reposense/RepoSense/issues/2317" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**47 :octicon-issue-opened:** (created issue #2317: Add File Pinning/Starring Feature to Highlight Key Files)
</div>

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 03 17:51:44]%%

### What feature(s) would you like to see in RepoSense
To complement the repository blurb feature, we can have a feature to allow users to pin or star specific files in their commits. These files would appear at the top of the file list in the RepoSense report, making them easier to access. Users can mention the files in the blurb and highlight these files using the pinning/starring feature.

### Is the feature request related to a problem?
In large commits, important files can get buried in long lists, making it time-consuming to locate them repeatedly.

### If possible, describe the solution
After configuration, a "Pin" or "Star" button would appear at the files. Pinning/Starring it would move the file to a pinned section at the top of the list in Code Panel.


</panel>

### Proposed solution
Renaming title.md

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 23 23:51:54]%%

I think testing for a `null` search key is similar to testing missing search key because the http request will also return `null` [https://jakarta.ee/specifications/servlet/6.1/apidocs/jakarta.servlet/jakarta/servlet/servletrequest#getParameter(java.lang.String)](https://jakarta.ee/specifications/servlet/6.1/apidocs/jakarta.servlet/jakarta/servlet/servletrequest#getParameter(java.lang.String)). Even if it's added, it should be part of the unit tests for the `Action` class.

For testing empty string search key, it actually behaves the same as a normal search query. Its behavior depends entirely on how we mock the search logic using `when(mockLogic.searchStudentsInWholeSystem(searchKey)).thenReturn(...)` or `when(mockLogic.searchStudents(searchKey, instructors)).thenReturn(...)`. So testing it does not provide any additional value.
</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 10 15:18:53]%%

> Seems like a good improvement to allow `MockEmailSender` to fail when required. Would it be better to throw an exception instead?

It would be better not to throw an exception in this case because the current usage pattern expects a return value indicating the status of the email sending operation. Specifically, the code looks like this:

'''java
EmailSendingStatus status = emailSender.sendEmail(email);
'''

After that, the status is checked with:

'''java
status.isSuccess();
'''

</panel>

- A frontend re-render issue causing duplicate entries to appear.
- Improper state management leading to multiple insertions.

**Environment**: Production environment

<panel type="warning" popup-url="https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/issues/13228" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**56 :octicon-issue-opened:** (created issue #13228: Standardize the Naming Convention for FeedbackSession Actions)
</div>

%%[created at: 2025 Feb 12 15:38:30]%%

## Description:

There are inconsistencies in the naming conventions for various `FeedbackSession` actions, which can cause confusion for contributors and maintainers. Terms like opening soon, opening, open, closing, and closed are used interchangeably without a clear pattern.

## Current Inconsistencies:

1. **Action Classes**:
    - `FeedbackSessionClosedRemindersAction`
    - `FeedbackSessionClosingRemindersAction`
    - `FeedbackSessionOpeningRemindersAction`
    - `FeedbackSessionOpeningSoonRemindersAction`

The terms "Closed" and "Closing" are clear and consistent, but for open sessions, the usage of "Opening" and "OpeningSoon" diverges from this pattern.

2. **Email Enabled Methods**:
    - `setClosingEmailEnabled()`  associated with emails that are sent 24 hours before the session closes.
    - `setOpeningEmailEnabled()`  associated with emails that are sent when the session opens.

## Suggestion:

Adopt a standardized naming convention using OpeningSoon, Opened, ClosingSoon, and Closed across all class names and methods.

1. **Class Name Adjustments**:
    - `FeedbackSessionOpeningRemindersAction`  `FeedbackSessionOpenedRemindersAction`
    - `FeedbackSessionClosingRemindersAction`  `FeedbackSessionClosingSoonRemindersAction`

2. **Method Adjustments**:
    - `setOpenEmailSent()`  `setOpenedEmailSent()`
    - `getFeedbackSessionsWhichNeedOpenEmailsToBeSent()`  `getFeedbackSessionsWhichNeedOpenedEmailsToBeSent()`

3. **Variable Name Adjustments**:
    - `isOpenEmailSent`  `isOpenedEmailSent`
    - `isOpeningEmailEnabled`  `isOpenedEmailEnabled`
    - `isClosingEmailEnabled`  `isClosingSoonEmailEnabled`

4. **CronJob URI Adjustments**:
    - Update CronJobURIs to reflect the class name changes for uniformity.
</panel>

<panel type="warning" popup-url="https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/issues/13261" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**57 :octicon-issue-opened:** (created issue #13261: Allow MockEmailSender to Simulate Email Sending Failures)
</div>

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 10 13:40:26]%%

Currently, the method `sendEmail(email)` in `MockEmailSender` class will always succeed when being called, making it impossible to test failure scenarios.

'''java
public class MockEmailSender extends EmailSender ``{``

    private List&lt;EmailWrapper> sentEmails = new ArrayList&lt;>();

    @Override
    public EmailSendingStatus sendEmail(EmailWrapper email) ``{``
        sentEmails.add(email);
        return new EmailSendingStatus(HttpStatus.SC_OK, null);
    ``}``

    // ...
``}``
'''

Since failure behavior is external and `MockEmailSender` should extend the method descriptors of the actual class, I propose adding a `shouldFail` class field. This would allow us to manually set the method to fail during testing.
</panel>

<panel type="warning" popup-url="https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/issues/13263" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**58 :octicon-issue-opened:** (created issue #13263: NullPointerException in Student class methods when student team is null)
</div>

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 11 03:45:14]%%

A `NullPointerException` occurs in the `Student` class when calling `getTeamName()`, `getSection()`, or `getSectionName()` on a student instance that has no team.

The `Student` class has two constructors:

- One that accepts a `team` parameter

- One that does not include a `team` parameter

When a student is created using the constructor without a team, the `team` field remains `null`.
However, the methods `getTeamName()`, `getSection()`, or `getSectionName()` do not perform null checks before accessing team properties, leading to a `NullPointerException`.

**Proposed Solution**

Add null checks to the affected methods to prevent exceptions.

Example fix for `getTeamName()`:

'''java
@Override
public String getTeamName() ``{``
    return getTeam() != null ? getTeam().getName() : null;
``}``
'''

A similar approach should be applied to `getSection()` and `getSectionName()`.
</panel>

<hr class="thick-1 border-secondary" />

<panel type="warning" popup-url="https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/issues/13275" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**59 :octicon-issue-opened:** (created issue #13275: Potential incorrect sending of closing soon email)
</div>

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 18 05:07:57]%%

The current query in `getFeedbackSessionEntitiesPossiblyNeedingClosingSoonEmail()` includes sessions where `endTime > TimeHelper.getInstantDaysOffsetFromNow(-2)`. This means sessions that ended up to 2 days ago are still being considered, which is incorrect.

**Proposed Solution:**

Correct the time range condition to ensure only sessions that are actually closing soon are selected.
</panel>

<panel type="warning" popup-url="https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/issues/13291" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**61 :octicon-issue-opened:** (created issue #13291: PostgreSQL port conflict when running dev server)
</div>

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 26 23:14:50]%%

When running `./gradlew serverRun`, the application attempts to connect to PostgreSQL. However, if a local PostgreSQL instance is already running on port `5432`, it conflicts with the Dockerized PostgreSQL instance, causing authentication failures and preventing the dev server from starting.

**Error:**
```
org.postgresql.util.PSQLException: FATAL: password authentication failed for user "teammates"
```

**Possible solutions:**
1. Add this issue in the Developer Troubleshooting Guide instructing developers to manually kill the local PostgreSQL server process if they encounter this issue.
2. Modify the `docker-compose.yml` and write a bash script to dynamically find an available port before running the dev server.
</panel>

<panel type="warning" popup-url="https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/issues/13323" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**66 :octicon-issue-opened:** (created issue #13323: Entities created during E2E tests persist in the database)
</div>

%%[created at: 2025 Apr 26 22:42:10]%%

Currently, `doRemoveAndRestoreDataBundle` does not fully clean up entities created dynamically during a test, such as when `FeedbackQuestion` is copied.

This happens because `removeSqlDataBundle` only deletes entities that are listed in the given `SqlDataBundle`. Entities created during the test are not included in the original `SqlDataBundle` and therefore persist in the database after the test finishes.

**Example**
When I repeatedly run the test and execute some scripts in the browser console, I observe that more and more question forms accumulate in that same feedback session.
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/f27fe771-1a36-4532-ab58-473adfc19b5c)
</panel>

> After looking through a bit of the code, what I'm understanding is that when you delete the session, it changes the database values and it persists across tests. When it reinitialises with a fresh JSON data bundle, it sends a PUT request to the server with that JSON data and compares the JSON data with the server. It only deletes if they match because they use PUT request. However, since it doesn't match, a PUT request will update the data values to the same as the JSON values. This is followed by a POST request to insert the JSON values into the db. By doing that, it is trying to insert already existing values and so it fails.
> 
> I didn't look into the postgres code so I cannot say that this is indeed the cause but this is what I kinda understood from the rabbit hole, hopefully it helps!

Hi @jasonqiu212, I tried this, but it doesnt seem to work.

Fetching archived courses only interacts with the datastore logic, which automatically sets `isCourseMigrated` to `true` by default. Because of this, in lines 123-125 of `GetCoursesAction.java`, the filter method that checks `isCourseMigrated` causes the returned course list to always be empty.

As a result, when attempting to retrieve archived courses using the new SQL logic, we always end up with an empty array list.
</panel>

<panel type="warning" popup-url="https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/issues/13326" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**82 :octicon-issue-opened:** (created issue #13326: Poor data cleanup after the SQL E2E tests leads to unexpected errors when running E2E tests)
</div>

%%[created at: 2025 Apr 30 16:14:02]%%

## Steps to reproduce
1. In an E2E test, call `feedbackEditPage.deleteSession()`.  
2. Run the E2E test suite once.  
3. Run the same E2E test suite again using the same json file for the E2E test,

## Expected behaviour
- All entities created during the test should be deleted.  
- Each E2E test run should start with a fresh database state, without any persisted values from previous runs.  

## Actual behaviour
- The second test run fails with: `teammates.common.exception.HttpRequestFailedException: Request failed: [409] ``{``"message":"Some entities in the databundle already exist","requestId":"586c09236d8bd7333f5f37de7b98217c"``}```.

**Additional info**
- The bug is further discussed in this PR: [[#12048] Migrate InstructorFeedbackEditPageE2ETest #13314](https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/issues/13324).
- However, it is unfixed at the moment.
&lt;!-- You can enter any additional relevant info here. -->
&lt;!-- If you know what caused the bug and/or how to resolve the bug, you can include them in this section. -->
- The only way to fix this issue is to change the JSON entity names. 
</panel>

``{``"message":"Some entities in the databundle already exist","requestId":"586c09236d8bd7333f5f37de7b98217c"``}`` at teammates.test.AbstractBackDoor.removeAndRestoreSqlDataBundle(AbstractBackDoor.java:280) at teammates.e2e.cases.sql.BaseE2ETestCase.doRemoveAndRestoreDataBundle(BaseE2ETestCase.java:238) at teammates.test.BaseTestCaseWithSqlDatabaseAccess.removeAndRestoreDataBundle(BaseTestCaseWithSqlDatabaseAccess.java:48) at teammates.e2e.cases.sql.InstructorFeedbackEditPageE2ETest.prepareTestData(InstructorFeedbackEditPageE2ETest.java:33) at teammates.e2e.cases.sql.BaseE2ETestCase.baseClassSetup(BaseE2ETestCase.java:58) at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method) at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:77) at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43) at java.base/java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:568) at org.testng.internal.invokers.MethodInvocationHelper.invokeMethod(MethodInvocationHelper.java:141) at org.testng.internal.invokers.MethodInvocationHelper.invokeMethodConsideringTimeout(MethodInvocationHelper.java:71) at org.testng.internal.invokers.ConfigInvoker.invokeConfigurationMethod(ConfigInvoker.java:400) at org.testng.internal.invokers.ConfigInvoker.invokeConfigurations(ConfigInvoker.java:333) at org.testng.internal.invokers.TestMethodWorker.invokeBeforeClassMethods(TestMethodWorker.java:188) at org.testng.internal.invokers.TestMethodWorker.run(TestMethodWorker.java:128) at java.base/java.util.concurrent.Executors$RunnableAdapter.call(Executors.java:539) at java.base/java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.run(FutureTask.java:264) at org.testng.internal.thread.graph.TestNGFutureTask.run(TestNGFutureTask.java:22) at java.base/java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1136) at java.base/java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:635) at java.base/java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:840) Re-trying removeAndRestoreDataBundle`
> 
> Without the lines `149-155`, I can pass all the test cases without issue multiple times. Would appreciate any insight from anybody, thanks!

After looking through a bit of the code, what I'm understanding is that when you delete the session, it changes the database values and it persists across tests. When it reinitialises with a fresh JSON data bundle, it sends a PUT request to the server with that JSON data and compares the JSON data with the server. It only deletes if they match because they use PUT request. However, since it doesn't match, a PUT request will update the data values to the same as the JSON values. This is followed by a POST request to insert the JSON values into the db. By doing that, it is trying to insert already existing values and so it fails.

I didn't look into the postgres code so I cannot say that this is indeed the cause but this is what I kinda understood from the rabbit hole, hopefully it helps!
</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Apr 05 14:00:38]%%

Data migration initiated by PR #12048.
Partially completed in #13254 (once this is merged, feel free to contribute).

## Issue
&lt;!-- Issue title: Data Migration: [summary of affected entities and fields] -->
After most of the Unit Tests migration in #12048, there were a lot of inconsistencies in access controls. This issue aims to improve the inconsistency of the migration as `BaseActionTest.java` had minimal migration in Access Controls.

## Status
As of the merging of #13254, all but `SubmitFeedbackResponsesActionTest.java` Unit Tests have been migrated. Following that, the progress for this refactoring can be found [here](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1IcB-viJMrIOknYoBYasBuRBK9qnwY0-doEK4_Eb24IA/edit?gid=0#gid=0). I may periodically update the sheets if anyone successfully merge new PRs.

## Contribution
The refactoring for most tests are quite straightforward. I have reviewed and refactored until `GetFeedbackQuestionRecipientsActionTest.java` in the sheets above (~50% of the tests). The remaining ones are for contributors who are new and would like to start somewhere easy. 

If you would like to contribute, check the sheets and comments for already migrated tests before starting. Do understand the methods in `BaseActionTest.java`, follow the refactoring in #13254, and ensure that all unit tests and linting passes before submitting your PR. Please comment which tests you intend to touch on so other contributors do not conflict with yours.

</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Apr 12 14:55:46]%%

Here's two suggestions to help out new developers that could help with confusion (which it did for me).
- When downloading `chromedriver`, the link provided for it shows an old version of `chromedriver` before Chrome v115. It takes two further clicks to find the right page for the latest version of Chrome (currently v135 for stable). I think it would be great if we can relink it to either the [Version Selection Page](https://developer.chrome.com/docs/chromedriver/downloads/version-selection) or the download links for the latest version [here](https://googlechromelabs.github.io/chrome-for-testing/), and highlight specifically to download `chromedriver`, and not `chrome` or `chrome-headless-shell` since I think most devs will not be running such an old version of chrome anyways.
- We could specify what does E2ETryTest1 to 5 means, and that there's also an Sql version too.

Edit: Here's an unrelated suggestion but I think it's not worth a separate PR for: In the Getting Started/Setting Up and all other pages which uses the same line, the line "Replace ./gradlew to gradlew.bat if you are using Windows." could have the word "to" changed to "with".
</panel>

%%[created at: 2024 Jul 23 15:07:54]%%

While this works, would it be better to take advantage of the auto scaling capabilities of css? 
We can avoid these breakpoints and corresponding values since the parent colspan of 7 scales according to screen size already, such that the children widths are always relative to the parent without changing their individual colspan or the parents. 
In order to preserve the full child item being shown when the screen shrinks, consider instead using min-width/max-width css properties with media queries to shift responsiveness logic to css where possible.
</panel>
