%%[created at: 2025 Jan 19 23:25:50]%%

Should groups be forced into the hidden list? 
The functionality of the hidden list is to display information about which groups happen to be hidden because of the filters selected. 
The use of this function to specify unique behaviour for groups that shouldn't be shown in the hidden list even when they are empty, such as the NO_ASSIGNEE group.
Forcing groups into the hidden list goes against this single responsibility and erodes into the responsibility of the filters.
</panel>

<panel type="success" popup-url="https://github.com/CATcher-org/WATcher/pull/389#discussion_r1921579054" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**20 :octicon-code-review:** (review on PR #389)
</div>

%%[created at: 2025 Jan 19 23:28:09]%%

Should the group service be used as a condition to hide cards? 
Hiding based on the group service erodes into the function of filtering where group service is only meant to group, not filter.
</panel>

<panel type="success" popup-url="https://github.com/CATcher-org/WATcher/pull/389#discussion_r1921580203" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**21 :octicon-code-review:** (review on PR #389)
</div>

%%[created at: 2025 Jan 19 23:34:35]%%

Should the filtersService contain a method to return a list of filtered assignees?
The filters service has the single responsibility of housing filters used throughout the application. Therefore the most updated filters should already be within the filter$ observable, handled by the component updating the filter. This method goes against this responsibility and its implementation even outside the filters service shouldn't happen since it implies an error in the use of the filters service.
</panel>

</div>

%%[created at: 2025 Jan 23 19:49:03]%%

Upon further research into the dependency tree, I have found the updated dependency is ``engine.io@6.6.3``, a deeply nested dependency of ``karma`` that just released a new version as of the afternoon of 23/1/25. This in turn depends on ``cookie@1.0.2``, causing our node dependency errors.
Instead of upgrading the node version which might lead to many unforseen incompatibility in production with our packages, a safer fix for now would be to explicitly require ``engine.io@6.6.2``.
In the long term, we should upgrade the angular version, node version and corresponding packages carefully to satisfy the dependency.
</panel>

%%[created at: 2024 Feb 21 12:25:41]%%

Hi, thanks for the PR @jingting1412! I've taken a look at the template, and I just have a few broad comments / suggestions that has to do with the UI / UX rather than the implementation itself:

- For a student portfolio, I would imagine that a sleek look would be preferred instead of too much clutter (though we could assume that this would be their first ever portfolio that they are setting up). 
  - I think we can reduce the clutter in the top navbar to only contain the GitHub and the LinkedIn logo - the search function is unlikely to be used, and the topics on the sidebar should be sufficient for navigation, since we aren't expecting a particularly lengthy site.
  - Breadcrumbs may not be needed for the same reason - the site is unlikely to be too lengthy. 
- I think we can include "Skills" and "Experience" as topics on the main page rather than as a separate page?
  - "Skills" can be the set of tech that the student has used previously, so I'm thinking of maybe having three [Panels](https://markbind.org/userGuide/components/presentation.html#panels) titled "Languages", "Frameworks & Tools", and "Others" respectively. And within those panels, maybe we can include examples for these. The two portfolio links that @yucheng11122017 posted has some possible examples.
  - It would be nice to present "Experience" as a simple timeline similar to how LinkedIn presents it, so [Boxes](https://markbind.org/userGuide/components/presentation.html#boxes) might be suitable here? It might be also useful to make use of the vertical line created by a [Blockquote](https://markbind.org/userGuide/formattingContents.html#blockquotes) here.
- The main container on the main page can be used to display: Name, short description, and profile image. Basically, embed the "Hello there! ..." section's current content into the black container instead of repeating the same-ish content twice.
- We could add some styling for the individual projects pages as well, similar to the layouts used by the two aforementioned portfolio links!
- The "Navigating this site" section will need to be updated - and maybe we can also include some information indicating that this portfolio is a simplified version (if we do decide to remove some navbar features, etc), and if the student wants access to more features, they can use other templates instead.

These are suggestions rather than directions, and feel free to counter these if you feel that they are not preferable :+1: 
</panel>

%%[created at: 2024 Jun 16 00:52:30]%%

Instead of making this change (since we rely on the conversions from slots to templates, and do not use header templates directly in our `.vue` files), a suggestion I have is to just directly treat the `header` as a prop instead, without relying on slot conversion?

In `Dropdown.vue`, we can first include the `header` as a prop:

```
props: ``{``
  ...
  header: ``{``
    type: String,
    default: '',
  ``}``,
  ...
```

And then we can replace the `<slot name="header"></slot>` under the `v-if`, with ```{`` header ``}```. We could also rename `header` to something like `tabgroup-header` to differentiate it as well.

This might be a less hacky solution, but if we can investigate the issue deeper and find a better solution, that would be best  
</panel>

<panel type="success" popup-url="https://github.com/MarkBind/markbind/pull/2557#issuecomment-2170302867" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**22 :octicon-code-review:** (review on PR #2557)
</div>

%%[created at: 2024 Jun 16 00:46:21]%%

> I don't quite understand how the Vue component's prop is being passed as a named slot. Referring to the [developer guide](https://markbind.org/devdocs/devGuide/development/writingComponents.html), I tried to trace the processing but I think I might be facing a skill issue. I'm confused as it says that "MarkBind attributes are passed to the Vue component as props. The type of the prop will be a String." However, the prop is able to be processed as a named slot.

The [`createSlotTemplateNode`](https://github.com/MarkBind/markbind/blob/master/packages/core/src/html/elements.ts#L11-L13) method is used to convert slots into template nodes directly; this is called by the [`processAttributeWithoutOverride`](https://github.com/MarkBind/markbind/blob/master/packages/core/src/html/MdAttributeRenderer.ts#L30-L50) method, which is in turned called for specified named slots that we are looking out for. This is how we process named slots - hopefully this addresses your question (and if it doesn't, do let me know).

Regardless, this issue might need further investigation  
</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Jan 15 12:16:47]%%

As discussed previously, this is a fantastic addition to MarkBind!

Something to consider after this PR would be the usability aspect. Given that the existing search function (by header) differs from this one (by text), with neither being replacements for the other (and with valid use cases for both), what we should consider is:

How do we increase the visibility of this plugin? Is documentation sufficient for users to be able to find and use this plugin, or should we actively include it in our templates? (And if so, how do we arrange / prioritise the two search functions in the UI?)

As mentioned during the group discussion, [SICP JS](https://sourceacademy.nus.edu.sg/sicpjs/3.2.1) in Source Academy handles this problem by putting both search functions side-by-side. By this train of thought, it might be worthwhile to make both of the search functions into modular components.
</panel>

<panel type="success" popup-url="https://github.com/MarkBind/markbind/pull/2568#issuecomment-2593164492" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**24 :octicon-code-review:** (review on PR #2568)
</div>

%%[created at: 2025 Jan 15 23:19:12]%%

> To add, the ideal outcome is that this plugin replaces both the current search (i.e., headers only) feature and the need to use third party search.

During the discussion with @gerteck, the point made was that searching by header and searching by text have somewhat different use cases and each of them might be necessary for different situations (especially since MarkBind tends to be header-heavy given its use case). If the initial goal was to replace the current search with this plugin, then I think we should consider one of these:

1. Either make this new plugin into a component & make it the default search on current templates (for easier use & to establish it as the "default"), or:
2. Find a way to integrate the two components into one (maybe there can be an overarching search component with a toggle between header-search and text-search via a prop?)

Of course, keeping in mind that this is out of scope for this PR & we may have to open a new issue to continue discussing this (@gerteck feel free to start this discussion issue), also given this comment:

> there will be a need for further analysis of the cost and benefit of making certain plugins default and increasing the usability/visibility of the features of each plugin.
</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Feb 16 16:30:10]%%

We can use [optional chaining](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/Optional_chaining) here, i.e.

'''suggestion
      const labelSlotContent = this.$scopedSlots.label?.();
      const headerSlotContent = this.$scopedSlots.header?.();

      const labelText = labelSlotContent?.[0]?.children?.[0]?.text;
      const labelHeader = headerSlotContent?.[0]?.children?.[0]?.text;
'''

You can probably combine these to compact them even further but I think this is fine enough considering readability.
</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Feb 16 11:38:27]%%

> Besides just IP addresses, should we also allow for hostnames like "localhost"?
> 
> In general, what should we count as a valid host for MarkBind?

Yes, we should allow for `localhost`. Beyond that, custom hostnames would be difficult to account for without allowing a wide range of allowed hostnames that are potentially invalid as well. But given that it would have worked fine until now, we should certainly look into how we can accommodate for this.

> Allow for IPV6 addresses to be specified (though I dont see much reason a user might want to use it, except maybe for the shorthand for localhost ::1)

We certainly should, by the same logic: if it is possible now for a user to use it (and it is valid), then it should still be possible. Anyway, ipv6 addresses are definitely valid use cases.

> Allow users to specify port number along with the IP address (the current implementation automatically redirects to a different port number if the default port is being used), though again, I don't quite see why users might want to specify separate ports

The [`-p` flag](https://markbind.org/userGuide/cliCommands.html#serve-command) is meant for specifying port numbers, so this wouldn't be necessary.
</panel>

> I believe we should still leave users with the choice to make the annotations clickable but with a better indication that it is still clickable.

Having the pointer change on hover for clickable items is certainly good; but for popovers (i.e. activated on hover and not by clicking; clicking does nothing), I'm wondering if the cursor change is necessary. Pointer changes should indicate that something can be activated via clicking

%%[created at: 2025 Feb 27 14:29:29]%%

I think being clickable implies that there is action that you can do on click; for this case, when you hover, a popover appears; you can click it once to make it disappear, but after that, subsequent clicks will not trigger any action. So from that perspective, I think it might be worth a look to see if it is worth removing the cursor change on hover for these cases.

Regardless, it seems that this is not behavior introduced in this PR - maybe this can be discussed in a separate issue / PR. For this PR itself, I have no further issues.

</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Apr 13 14:48:00]%%

> I think there was a typo. What I meant was something like `1[:]#00ff00` or `1[:]#y`. I think in general putting both hex color codes and color names after the same # will not lead to confusion? Correct me if I am wrong.

On the contrary, given that the convention is to have `#` for color hex codes and not for names (e.g. "red" or "blue"), having `#` would not be consistent with standard color notation conventions. Moreover, I don't think I would like the additional logic we would have to implement (e.g. check if string is 6 or 3 letters containing hexadecimal to decide if it is hex or not) - seems unnecessary. I think using `@` is perfectly fine. 

I agree that the usage of the color highlighting makes the string quite complex though. The example given: 

```
java ``{``.line-numbers highlight-lines="1[:]@pink,3['Inventory']@blue,3[4::6]@orange,4['It\'s designed']@#000000,5@rgb(120, 130, 250),6[8:15]@purple,6[18:]@yellow,8[0::2],12[:]-14,16-18,20[12:]-22,24[1::]-26"``}``
```

This is quite unreadable to me at this point, and if the person wants more organized color highlighting for their code (e.g. highlight whenever certain keywords appear), this will be quite annoying to modify one by one. I think it's certainly going to be worth discussing how to improve this feature. 

But as a first stage implementation, I think this is a good first step.


</panel>

<div slot="header">

**133 :octicon-issue-opened:** (created issue #2387: Allow dynamic updates to MarkBind Templates)
</div>

%%[created at: 2024 Jan 20 11:24:07]%%

### Please confirm that you have searched existing issues in the repo

Yes, I have searched the existing issues

### Any related issues?

#2384, #2385, #2386

### What is the area that this feature belongs to?

_No response_

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.

With the addition of new templates in #2384, #2385, and #2386, we should look into ways to dynamically update specific sections of MarkBind Templates as MarkBind constantly updates (as mentioned [here](https://github.com/MarkBind/markbind/issues/2386#issuecomment-1900636012)). This will require us to identify which sections of templates are more prone to changes (e.g. MarkBind components) and which sections are not (e.g. Template-specific content). 

### Describe the solution you'd like

There are existing .njk files for site generation (mainly used for `init --convert`), e.g. `packages/core/src/Site/siteConvertLayout.njk`. We can consider extending this idea to newer templates to allow for dynamic site generation, meaning that we will have fewer files to be edited. However, this will likely be limited mainly to the `default.md` and other `.md` files for the templates.

Regardless of whether the above is feasible or not, long-term maintainability will need to be considered in the future as we continue to add more templates.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

If we can do something similar (either automate the process via CLI commands, or at least provide a guide to PWA-ifying a MarkBind site), this can prove quite useful. Offline functionality for static sites seem very promising IMO.

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.

This is a feature idea that I have been thinking about for some time: a developer tool for MarkBind testing and experimentation. (And this does not need to be restricted to developers only, either)

### Describe the solution you'd like

What I envision is a live editing tool for MarkBind; imagine an IDE on the left hand side, and a MarkBind live preview on the right hand side (think Overleaf). The IDE can help add components (e.g. add in the table syntax) or add formatting directly via buttons (like a document editor), instead of having to look up the documentation on how to do so every time.

The benefits of this tool may be, and are not restricted to, the following:
- Allows for quick testing and experimenting with MarkBind for users
- Allows developers to quickly test if new changes are working
- If we can link this up to GitHub CI/CD, this can make PR testing for components a lot quicker and easier

Of course, going to the PR branch, pulling the changes (or using `gh` CLI tool), and creating test sites to test new changes is still available. `markbind serve -d` allows for live preview of MarkBind sites. Therefore, this issue is **not urgent or mandatory**, given that all of these can already be done. However, I still think that consolidating the testing process into a single tool, and integrating it into GitHub CI/CD, will be more than beneficial for MarkBind in the long term.

Note: #572 is not relevant; the title seems so, but #572 focuses more on within MarkBind sites.

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 11 22:05:56]%%

After some thought and moving people around into different teams, I have the following proposal:

Teams:

- admin: admin access, for mentors and team leads (selected cs3282 students)
   - release managers: admin access, for selected 3282 students who will be making new releases
- developers: push access, for cs3282 students (past and present)
   - junior developers: push access, for cs3281 students (after recess week)
- contributors: triage access, for all contributors to MarkBind
  - active contributors: triage access, for all active contributors

Initially I wanted to try this approach:

> CS3281 students gradually gain more access to the repository as they become more familiar with it, so it is easier to make them part of a team and adjust the permissions for the whole group as the timeline dictates.

But given that GitHub child teams inherit the permissions of the parent teams, this means that CS3281 students will have to be placed in a completely new team separate from contributors and senior developers (with triage and push access respectively), as we don't want to change the permissions for non-CS3281 contributors to push access, or for senior developers to triage access.

So now we are following this approach:

> I think keeping the number of teams small and remove/add members to the teams with correct permission might be easier to follow.

Workflows:

- Non-CS328X developers:
  - When a developer non-trivially contributes to MarkBind, they can be added into the contributors team. 
  - When a developer contributes multiple times to MarkBind and is active, they can be added into the active contributors child team.
- CS3281 students:
  - CS3281 students will first be added into the contributors team before the semester begins (if they have contributed to MarkBind).
  - They will be added to the contributors team and the active contributors child team once the semester begins. This will allow them to be pinged. 
  - At the end of the recess week, we often give more permissions to CS3281 students for them to start managing; this is when they will be added to the junior developers child team, with push access. 
  - At the end of the semester, they will be moved from the junior developers child team to the developers team.
  - At the end of each CS3281 semester (and beginning of each CS3281 semester), the junior developers team should be empty.
- CS3282 students:
  - CS3282 students should begin in the developers team, following the above approach; a few (or all) from a batch will be selected to be mentors and/or release managers, and will be added to the admin and/or release managers teams accordingly.

@tlylt @kaixin-hc @damithc does this approach make sense? We could also potentially make it even clearer by renaming "developers" to "CS328X" and "junior developers" to "CS3281", since these two teams (with push access) would pretty much only be used for CS328X students (past and present).
</panel>

The question for this example is asking for: which of the options **contradicts** the heuristics recommended? 

The idea is that the first option is **correct**, meaning that it **does not contradict** the heuristics recommended, hence **not the correct option to be chosen here**. The question is intended to be single-answer, with the 4th option being the correct answer.

The tip (for multiple correct answers) that follows the question is standalone, and there is no example provided for this.

So the UG example is also actually correct. The issue is not in the correctness here, but in the wording. I think we just need to make the following documentation changes:

1. Re-word the reasoning for the first option from "correct" to "does not contradict the heuristics recommended".
2. Provide another example of a question with multiple correct options.
</panel>

<panel type="info" popup-url="https://github.com/MarkBind/markbind/issues/2587#issuecomment-2615740471" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**160 :octicon-comment:** (commented on issue #2587)
</div>

%%[created at: 2025 Jan 27 21:17:32]%%

> Would it be better if this was left as a tip instead? Though allowed, according to proper heuristics, if there are multiple correct answers, users should choose to use a checkbox question instead of a multiple choice question.

I don't think this is true for all cases - I would consider an MCQ question with multiple correct answers vs. a Checkbox question with multiple correct answers to be two different use cases. (The first case might be useful if a question setter wants to be more "lenient" in a textbook quiz)

Leaving it as a tip is likely not going to cause huge problems per se, but given that (1) this issue was raised since the tip was initially thought to refer to the example above the tip, and (2) we can have more examples as needed (we are doing it for the [Fill-in-the-Blanks Questions section](https://markbind.org/userGuide/components/others.html#fill-in-the-blanks-questions)), it might be worthwhile to at least clear up the potential confusion.

If providing an example seems to be overkill, we can expand / reword the tip so that there is no ambiguity, i.e. make it clear that the example shown is meant to be a single-answer question.
</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 27 22:55:15]%%

In my opinion, we should not remove this feature. We should continue allowing repo-granularity since dates and until dates.
  - I think it makes little sense to remove all the work done in #2281. I recall the initial plan was to use it for trimming but ever since we have the trimming done in the front end, it seemed underutilized. That being said, I think it is still a good feature to keep. 
    1) Allows for more flexibility for users, use cases maybe we haven't thought of. 
    2) The work is already done anyway. 
    3) #2217 This is still a requested feature
    - A possible use case for this is that users could possibly want to omit all commits prior to a certain date just for one repo. For example, limiting the scope of commits to just Week 1 to Week 13 of a school semester. Any commits done before Week 1 doesn't count for credit, any done after Week 13 doesn't count for credit.
  - Yes, it will require us to deconflict between CLI and CSV input, and the interactions that will happen on the front end for trimming and filtering for both normal mode and portfolio mode. But I think this can be deconflicted. Scenarios will need to be noted down. Definitions (like trimming) will also need to be noted down in the reference.

### Deconflicting between CLI `--since`, `--until` flags and CSV per repo `Since Date`, `Until Date`

#### Overlapping dates

> There may be a case which repos specified hardcoded time ranges that are non-overlapping and far away from one another.

Suppose a date range A-B-C-D:

For these overlapping cases, I think they are user misconfigurations and should be treated as such. It doesn't make sense for the user to use `--since A --until C` and `Since Date: B`,`Until Date: D`. Is this the overlapping case you are talking about? What would make sense is for the user to either 1) expand the CLI flags `--until` to cover date range until D, or 2) reduce the CSV `Until Date` to C.

For this case, we will throw an error from the backend and stop thet report generation since this is a user input error. We can then give a meaningful error message in the veins of: `Error: you specified in CLI a date range of --SINCE to --UNTIL, but your CSV config specifies a date range that extends outside --SINCE or --UNTIL. Either modify your CLI flags or your CSV date range.`

In summary, basically, CLI flags are used for the main bulk of the report generation, the CSV is just used to **limit the date range, not expand the date range beyond what's expected**. Our invariant is that the CLI flags must always be a superset of the CSV flags. An illustration of what I mentioned:

<img width="589" alt="Image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/1a02b936-25d7-4e42-aaac-cd09a5abac58" />

Side note: What is the current behavior regarding using CSV dates that falls outside the range of CLI dates, given the implemented feature in #2281? We might need to throw an error for that as that seems like an undefined behavior and should not be the case. 

#### Using CSV dates without using CLI date flags

Considering our default if we don't specify any CLI date flags. We use --since to be one month before the current date.

If the user specifies CSV dates without CLI date flags, I propose we can handle this by checking all the date ranges and finding the earliest start date and latest end date of all the repos, then we generate our report based on that inferred date range. We also let the user know with a warning: `You did not specify CLI date range but specified CSV date range. We will infer the maximum from the CSV date range given.`

#### How will it work with trim and filter in the FE?

By default I believe filter dates works based off the input --since and --until or whatever's inferred. So this shouldn't be impacted. 

As for trim, I think it is necessary to establish a definition of what it means, and we will use the current definition: first commit and last commit, and this is still possible since the CSV dates only serves to limit our date range of commits.

#### Inputs:

Requesting your inputs: @damithc Will this logic possibly detrack too far from the original intention? Since we are technically using the Since Date and Until Date in the CSV as limits if we do use the CLI flags (though if we don't use the CLI flags, this will serve the original intention of allowing multiple date for different repos, just that every repo requires a date range/otherwise should be inferred from the inputs.

Please help me see if i am missing any potential edge cases and also sanity for FE. Are there any considerations on FE side I may be missing?: @sopa301 @jonasongg @Airiinnn 

As the implementer, can you check if the logic is sound or needs further refinement? @CYX22222003 All these will need to be documented.

**All in all, I believe we can handle all these via aborting the RepoSense run if it is misconfigured, or warning the user if it is not a misconfiguration as in the case of no CLI flag inputs. It shouldn't be too difficult a change implementation wise.**
</panel>

<panel type="warning" popup-url="https://github.com/reposense/RepoSense/issues/2266" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**61 :octicon-issue-opened:** (created issue #2266: Fix Cypress tests that fail locally but pass on GitHub due to time zone difference)
</div>

%%[created at: 2025 Jan 20 16:55:09]%%

&lt;!--
  Before opening a new issue, please search existing issues:  https://github.com/reposense/RepoSense/issues
-->

### What feature(s) would you like to see in RepoSense
When running Cypress tests on a local machine (`./gradlew frontendTest` or otherwise), certain tests such as in `optimiseTimeline` will fail as the time zone of Singapore is different from that of the GitHub runner, and the tests are currently configured to pass on GitHub. This causes confusion to new contributors when running Cypress tests. Let's change this behaviour such that tests will pass on both local machines and on GitHub.

### If possible, describe the solution
There could be some Cypress configs that allow changing the time zone the tests are run in. Otherwise, some other workaround to ensure the tests that fail purely because of this time zone issue pass on local machines will work as well.

</panel>

-->

On a side note, the [Netlify deployment for RepoSense](https://app.netlify.com/sites/reposense/deploys) has been down since March 2024.

I agree that it would be nice to support CSV dates and the dynamic date range at the same time, as it essentially allows report viewers to view data ranges of interest. Using the backend to ensure that the ranges are validated would ensure we don't have empty charts, which I can't imagine a scenario where we would need them. An implemented behaviour for the frontend in #2303 would be to display an error message, but I agree that this could be caught earlier during report generation.

From my knowledge of the frontend, there should be no problem, since we only receive 1 set of `sinceDate` and `untilDate` per repo and 1 set for the overall report via `summary.json`.

Though, regarding the amount of effort and time to implement this on the backend, I'm not sure if it's feasible within the remainder of the semester. 

Since we already have implementations for the simplified behaviour, perhaps we could merge those first and collect user data, before we commit to the more comprehensive solution?
</panel>

<panel type="info" popup-url="https://github.com/reposense/RepoSense/issues/2334#issuecomment-2758678141" expanded>

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 28 00:34:25]%%

I believe that Si Kai was proposing that the CSV date ranges are meant to further restrict the range of commits to send to the frontend (correct me if I'm wrong), which is why the range must be a subrange of the CLI date range. So therefore on the frontend, those commits outside of the CSV date ranges essentially don't exist in the report, and so the filter range takes priority as usual. This is based off one interpretation of #2217, where "different time periods" means to limit the range of commits to different time periods per repo. The other interpretation would be to view "different time periods" as to fix the viewable range to fixed time periods, indicated via the CSV file, which is what #2340 does with the portfolio mode.

I also think it's worth separating users into report generators and report viewers, given that this is made with code portfolios in mind. I think it's reasonable that report generators will want to exclude certain commits from viewers, which Si Kai's solution would allow.
</panel>

<panel type="info" popup-url="https://github.com/reposense/RepoSense/issues/2334#issuecomment-2761947055" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**162 :octicon-comment:** (commented on issue #2334)
</div>

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 29 01:07:23]%%

Let's go with having the CSV file define the range of commits to fetch per repo. This way, we can avoid massive changes to frontend logic and allow our portfolio PR to proceed. So the behaviour will be as such per repo:

1. CSV line present, CLI present: Range of commits will be taken from CSV line, and CSV line will be validated against CLI line.
2. CSV line present, CLI absent: Range of commits taken from CSV line. Overall range is the union of all ranges across CSV-specified repos.
3. CSV line absent (already implemented): Range of commits taken from CLI (if any, else default values for CLI)

Behaviour for the other views (e.g. Author, Chart, None) should remain the same since this is a backend change.

There are edge cases for partial information provided (e.g. start date/end date only):
For CSV lines:
- If start date provided only, end date will be either 1: CLI end date if given, or 2: latest date across all CSV-specified repos
- If end date provided only, start date will be either 1: CLI start date if given, or 2: earliest date across all CSV-specified repos

CLI defaults without any CSV dates specified remain the same. We will raise warnings for any behaviour that diverges from CLI defaults (e.g. when CSV dates are specified but CLI is not)

This means the following actions will be taken:
- #2320 to be merged
- New PR to validate CSV inputs and make inferences where relevant to be created (#2340).

Does anyone have any thoughts/objections/suggestions?

P.S.:

> Also, if we're going with the filter range priority for default view, can I confirm that in portfolio mode, it should be handled 
> differently and the date indicators displayed are the individual repository date ranges (as how it is implemented in #2340)?

@Airiinnn, I forgot that portfolio mode removes the in-report date range filter, so there is actually a reason to diverge from default mode behaviour. My bad :P
</panel>

   If end date provided only, start date will be either 1: CLI start date if given, or 2: earliest date across all CSV-specified repos

%%[created at: 2025 Apr 03 00:52:56]%%

>Automerging defaults to using Pull Requests (automergeType="pr"). In that case Renovate first creates a branch and associated Pull Request, and then automerges the PR on a subsequent run once it detects the PR's status checks are "green". If by the next run the PR is already behind the base branch it will be automatically rebased, because Renovate only automerges branches which are up-to-date and green. If Renovate is scheduled for hourly runs on the repository but commits are made every 15 minutes to the main branch, then an automerge like this will keep getting deferred with every rebase.

We'll have to wait for a day where there's no merges in the previous day to check if the current config works properly.

For now, I'll merge the ones that pass CI to free up our CI resources.
</panel>

%%[created at: 2024 Jul 28 12:03:07]%%

Based on this branching, it is possible that the body contains the message for not having a `Fixes #<issue-number>` as well as the message for not addressing an open issue right? I would assume logic should work  something like this:
- If isDescriptionValid is false, it means the PR description doesn't contain a valid reference to an issue number.
- If isIssueOpen is checking whether the referenced issue is open (assuming it was implemented correctly), it wouldn't be able to perform this check if there's no valid issue reference in the description.

Based on the above, a more logical flow should look something like:

- Check if the description is valid (contains a proper issue reference)
- Only if the description is valid, then fetch and check the state of the referenced issue (I believe the issue number can be extracted using capture groups)

To use a capture group, the extraction process might look something like this (this is just an example, do test it out and verify)

```
const descriptionRegex = /(?:[Ff]ix(?:es|ed)?|[Cc]lose(?:s|d)?|[Rr]esolve(?:s|d)?|[Pp]art [Oo]f) #(\d+)/;
const extractIssueNum = (description) => ``{``
  const match = description.match(descriptionRegex);
  return match ? match[1] : null;
``}``;
const issueNumber = extractIssueNumber(pr.data.body);
```
</panel>

I believe that this throws an error because it tries to cast a non-uuid formatted string to a UUID? If so, then the test name should reflect the intent accordingly; i.e. this should be named `testExecute_markNotificationWithInvalidNotificationId_shouldFail` or something similar. Additionally, would be good to also add a test that checks for something non-existent, i.e. a valid UUID will throw a EntityNotFoundException.

Additionally, I believe this error should be caught and formatted correctly, i.e. caught and re-thrown as an InvalidParametersException. You can create a new issue (and even a PR to handle this if you'd like) to track this. But I think the action should be refactored to use `getUuidFromString` instead of UUID.fromString. 

Meanwhile I'm ok with merging this PR with this current assertion (as a follow up PR will need to refactor this test anyway)
</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Feb 15 16:36:15]%%

From the already migrated unit tests, I see another approach being used:

```
private Instructor instructor;

@BeforeMethod
void setUp() ``{``
  instructor = new Instructor(...);
``}``
```

`@BeforeMethod` annotation executes `setUp()` before each test method within a test class. I see the merits of using this, since we can reduce LoC for common typicalXXX objects and keep it consistent with the migrated tests

Perhaps we can standardize using the following approach:
- For creating typicalXXX objects that are common for all test methods within a test class, follow the above approach of using a `setUp()` method, so that a fresh typicalXXX object is created for each test method
- For typicalXXX objects that are **not** common for all test methods, create them in the test methods.
- Creating typicalXXX objects should use `getTypicalXXX()`, rather than instantiating the object directly using `new` for consistency
- If a test method requires attribute modifications, they should be done in the test methods themselves.

As an example:

```
private Instructor instructor;

@BeforeMethod
void setUp() ``{``
  instructor = getTypicalInstructor();
``}``

@Test
void testExecute_typicalCase_success() ``{``
  instructor.setName(...);
  ...
``}``
```

@domoberzin Do you think this would be better?
</panel>

thanks for this huge refactoring!! 

High-level structural changes:
- Change `private` methods that are possible to be called by test cases to `public`. To avoid duplicate code and extensibility
- For code clarity, we can still preserve the high-level and mid-level groups, as per the old `BaseActionTest`, but within the groups we should maintain order from admin -&gt; maintainer -&gt; instructor -&gt; student -&gt; unregistered -&gt; without login. Let's also add comments saying: we prefer this ordering for new access control methods + we prefer using high-level access control methods over mid-level ones

Nits:
- Pluralization should be standardized (plural for everything, except for AnyXXX)
- Change guest to `WithoutLogin`, since guest can still imply guest account
- verifyInstructorsCanAccess: Should clarify to `verifyAnyInstructorCanAccess`
- `instructorCanAccess`: change to just log in as instructor + can access -&gt; pass!
</panel>

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 24 15:50:33]%%

This code is correct! but I was just initially puzzled by how we can set weight to be `null` when it's of `number` type. Turns out we can.. by doing `const weight: number = null as any;` to bypass the type checking, and i think that's what we're doing here.

I think we should follow TypeScript's type safety as best as we can for both type safety and readability. Thus, I think we need to change the following:

Line 17: `weightPerOption: Record&lt;string, number | null> = ``{````}``;`

<panel type="warning" popup-url="https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/issues/13227" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**231 :octicon-issue-opened:** (created issue #13227: Improve documentation on testing)
</div>

%%[created at: 2025 Feb 11 14:47:11]%%

## Description

Currently, documentation on testing is spread into many pages, which may lead to confusion for budding developers. 

To summarize the pages that mention testing:
- [Workflow: Development](https://teammates.github.io/teammates/development.html#testing)
  - Contains: Overview of testing, Running frontend tests, Running backend tests
- [How-to: Unit Testing](https://teammates.github.io/teammates/unit-testing.html)
  - Contains: What is unit testing, Writing unit tests, Running frontend/backend tests
- [How-to: E2E Testing](https://teammates.github.io/teammates/e2e-testing.html)
  - Contains: What is E2E testing, Running E2E tests, Writing E2E tests
- [How-to: Performance Testing](https://teammates.github.io/teammates/performance-testing.html)
  - Contains: Creating performance tests, Running performance tests
- [How-to: Accessibility Testing](https://teammates.github.io/teammates/axe-testing.html)
  - Contains: What is accessibility testing, Running accessibility tests, Creating accessibility tests
- [How-to: Snapshot Testing](https://teammates.github.io/teammates/snapshot-testing.html)
  - Contains: What is snapshot testing, How does snapshot testing work, How do we use snapshot testing, When to use snapshot testing, Best Practices
- [Best Practices: Testing](https://teammates.github.io/teammates/best-practices/testing.html)

## Potential Areas of Confusion
- Duplicate content: https://teammates.github.io/teammates/unit-testing.html#running-tests and https://teammates.github.io/teammates/development.html#running-tests
- Inconsistent language: It's not really clear what's the difference between component tests and unit tests in TEAMMATES.
- Inconsistent content sequence: Most of the testing pages contain "how to **run** the tests" and "how to **write** the tests". But their order across pages is not consistent.
- In the documentation menu, the navlink for snapshot testing is not grouped together with the navlinks for the other tests. New developers interested in testing may miss out on snapshot testing as a result.

## Suggestions
- The testing section in the [Workflow: Development](https://teammates.github.io/teammates/development.html#testing) page should serve as a landing/entry page to all tests in TEAMMATES. The section should only contain links to the individual How-to pages. The hierarchy of tests should be defined clearly here.
- For all of the How-to pages on testing, "how to run the tests" should always precede "how to write the tests", since developers are more likely to run tests before writing any.
- Prefer links over duplicate content

Feel free to add/discuss/clarify the above potential areas of confusion and suggestions!
</panel>

<panel type="warning" popup-url="https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/issues/13309" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**234 :octicon-issue-opened:** (created issue #13309: Improve E2E Testing docs)
</div>

%%[created at: 2025 Apr 10 15:26:13]%%

In our [E2E Testing docs](https://teammates.github.io/teammates/e2e-testing.html), the instructions to setup the local testing environment is not clear. 

Some of my personal experiences when setting up E2E include:
- Setting `test.selenium.browser` to the correct browser is not mentioned. "e.g. to configure which browser and test accounts to use." seems to be the only relevant instruction? but that's not really explicit
- "Before running E2E tests, it is important to have the dev server running locally first if you are testing against it.": This line, which is essential to running the E2E tests, is obscurely hidden between FAQ-type notes. Imo, I think this should be part of the essential steps to setting up E2E testing. Also it should be specified that both the frontend and backend dev server need to be running, and that the frontend/backend url in `test.properties` needs to be changed accordingly
- If running FE and BE separately, need to change FE url to `4200`
- Make sure driver path is to the executable, not just the folder containing the executable
- For Mac users, chromedriver may be unidentified software, so need to allow in permissions
- "Using Firefox/Chrome/Edge": Downloading the relevant XXXdriver and specifying the path are essential steps. But these are also mixed with other FAQ-type notes, so new developers may miss out on reading these steps
- The troubleshooting guide answers a bunch of FAQs on E2E tests. I think the E2E testing docs should include a link to the troubleshooting guide
</panel>

UUID id = UUID.fromString((String) document.getFieldValue("id"));

It seems like the SolrDocument ID is a concatenation of email and institute, but the AccountRequest entity ID is a UUID

%%[created at: 2025 Feb 20 15:45:49]%%

Renaming the attributes in the entity code may introduce bugs as the names of these attributes in the backend datastore remain unchanged. If we want to rename the entity attributes we can use the `@AlsoLoad` annotation:

`@AlsoLoad("oldName") private boolean newName;`
</panel>

If keeping the DB column names unchanged but changing the name in the entity, you can use

`@Column(nullable = false, name = "&lt;COLUMN_NAME>")`

this way you should be able to keep the new names in the rest of the code & test data files as well

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 27 16:00:42]%%

Thanks for raising this issue! I managed to replicate the issue. However, manually clearing the cookies did not resolve the issue for me. I suspect the root cause is the Google login persisting rather than the TEAMMATES cookies  I'll investigate this a bit further to see if this is the case.

Steps to replicate:
1. Log in with a Google account not associated with any TEAMMATES account. This will display the "Ooops!" message.
2. Log out. This will redirect to home page, and it will appear to have logged out (top right will display "Login" instead of the gmail address)
3. Try to log in again.


</panel>

<panel type="info" popup-url="https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/issues/13292#issuecomment-2757647867" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**25 :octicon-comment:** (commented on issue #13292)
</div>

%%[created at: 2025 Mar 27 19:13:19]%%

After investigating this further, it seems like the issue of unexpectedly logging in again occurs when only 1 account is currently signed in to Google. With multiple accounts logged in to Google, trying to log in to TEAMMATES (step 3 above) shows Google's choose account screen. I think this is typical behavior for Firebase authentication.

2 possible solutions:
1. [Force the account picker screen for each login](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/62043170/firebase-google-auth-wont-let-me-choose-the-account-to-connect-with), which would make it obvious that the user is signing in again (vs auto account selection making it seem like they never logged out).
2. Edit the message to tell the user to log into Google _separately_ with the correct account before trying to log in to TEAMMATES again.
</panel>
